PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the latest bulletin of the Business Council of Australia which, on the result of a survey of firms, states:

QUESTION.PARA: Export values are expected to slow from 16 per cent to 7 per cent per annum . . . Import values are expected to grow from 9 per cent per annum to 13 per cent per annum.

I ask the minister: in the light of six out of the last seven current account deficits being over $2 billion, what is the government doing about this frightening forecast of even greater deterioration in our balance of payments? Is the government's only answer that which it tried in the late 1980s of forcing up interest rates to dampen demand? Hasn't the government learned any lessons from that experience?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the terms of that particular survey. I am not sure on what it is based, how comprehensive it is or how seriously the particular figures of Senator Hill should be taken. Our own estimate, as I have said in the last week or so in this place, is that we fully expect exports to pick up in the context of world recovery, in the context of better commodity prices and in the context of a continued effective penetration by Australian business of the regional market, in particular, which is continuing to expand at a dramatic rate. There is no particular reason to anticipate that there will be any serious downturn in exports. In fact, in respect of the period ahead, our confidence is very strong.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it is the case that imports can be expected to surge in the context of the present recovery and very strong growth that we are experiencing and, in particular, the very strong demand for capital goods. That is to be expected. But, of course, that is building a substantial and solid base for a productive future and ought, as a result, to be regarded as a cause for optimism about the future and our future capacity to penetrate those markets, rather than just focusing wholly on the short-term pessimism with which Senator Hill is so comfortable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a question of being comfortable. Actually, we on this side are particularly uncomfortable with what is happening in the country. But what we are asking is that the government take note of the messengers. It happened in the late 1980s when the messengers were telling the government that its policy was going to lead to a terrible recession. It ignored those messengers. Now the Business Council is saying to you that in fact its assessment, on the basis of what its member firms are saying to it, is much more pessimistic. Will you take note of that; will you recognise that, on top of the already terrible current account situation, there is the chance of further deterioration; and will you address it with policies other than simply pushing up interest rates?

—Yes, we will take notice of any sensibly based survey information which tells us something about expectations and about the psychology of the business community if not necessarily always about the actual facts on which things are based. Of course we will take notice of that, and of course we will continue with an economic policy which is not wholly premised on what monetary policy and what interest rates might be able to contribute to the necessary breaking of the economy. Of course we will concentrate very heavily on the fiscal side of the equation. That is what this budget is all about; we have made that perfectly clear.

PARA.TAB: We do have to do something about improving the savings base in this country. We do have to improve that in the public sector as well as in the private sector. Of course, that is what the fiscal arrangements that we will be bidding for and implementing in this budget are all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Given the level of public, media and industry interest in the allegations concerning the meat industry recently raised by the Community and Public Sector Union, I ask the minister to advise the Senate what steps he has taken to have the allegations investigated. Is the minister in a position to give the Senate any preliminary advice on the nature and scope of the allegations?

—The Community and Public Sector Union has given me a great deal of paper. Most of it comprises photocopies of acts of parliament and meat regulations. Fundamentally, the union has raised about half a dozen allegations. I believe that that was substantially what the union told the Senate committee last Friday—the members of the committee who were there would be able to confirm that. As I say, most of the paper that I have is photocopies of acts of parliament or regulations, but there are half a dozen or so allegations in that paper, most of which have been canvassed publicly before.

PARA.TAB: I gave a series of public undertakings to the union before receiving those documents that any allegations that were brought forward by the union would be rigorously pursued, and I am now in the process of doing that. In this regard, my office has formally written to the Australian Government Solicitor expressing my wish to obtain expert independent legal advice on the implications of the matters that have been raised in the paperwork that has been given to me by the CPSU. The Australian Government Solicitor has been asked to examine the documents and then advise me on what steps, if any, should be taken. Depending on that advice, I may ask that the documents be referred to other agencies for appropriate action.

I have informed the Australian Government Solicitor that the compliance legal and evaluation unit of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is available to assist in the examination of the documents. I might add for the information of honourable senators that that compliance unit of AQIS routinely handles quite a large number of complaints that are made from time to time to do with things, for example, like substituting mutton for lamb—a practice not confined to the meat industry, I might add. There is a fair bit of it around here at times.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a sexist remark.

—I was not talking about you, Ron, or me. I have informed the Australian Government Solicitor that the compliance legal and evaluation unit of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is available to assist in the examination of the documents. I repeat my previous public assurances that the results of this investigation will be made public.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to comments last week by President Clinton that the success of the Uruguay Round world trade deal in cutting farm export subsidies `should not be undermined by any effort unilaterally to reduce subsidies at home' and that he views the EEP as an important part of our ability to meet and match international competition. Considering the tremendous damage done to Australian primary industry by US subsidy programs—for example, the 90 per cent reduction in our sugar import quotas over the past 14 years and the $2.4 billion losses because of the subsidy trade war in the wheat industry—I ask: in view of the Uruguay Round agreements, is the US required to tariffy all its import quotas such as presently affect our beef and sugar industries? Does the government believe the US will introduce more subsidies before the start of the Uruguay Round? In what ways does the government believe it can influence the forthcoming US farm bill in view of President Clinton's recent words?

—I thank Senator Boswell for his question. I think it is the first opposition trade question I have had for some time. I am not aware of any fresh remarks made last week by President Clinton, but I am aware of comments he has made. I think we are referring to the same comments—I will not quibble about the timing. It is a cause of concern for Australia that, while we welcome the progress that has been made—I know Senator Boswell does and we all do—in the Uruguay Round, there is no sense in which Australia or any of the other Cairns Group countries believe that what was achieved is anything like sufficient. It was a useful first step. It is nothing like sufficient to say that we now have fair agricultural trading rules.

PARA.TAB: We have terribly unfair, distorted agricultural trading rules internationally which are particularly bad for Australia and for the other free traders in agriculture, particularly those in the Cairns Group. So we will continue to focus on the issues that you raised. I will start from the last issue you raised and work up.

The most important issue on which we will be focusing in 1995—and Senator Collins and I are working closely together on this with the industry—is the farm bill. The biggest decisions that will be made in the United States this year by Congress in determining the shape and nature of agricultural trade globally, but particularly to the United States and by the United States in other markets, will be in the farm bill.

We have convened a committee with representatives of all the major interested commodity groups and with Senator Collins and me. We are working on a coordinated strategy. I very much appreciate the cooperation of the commodity groups in that they have taken a series of delegations—the most publicised of which was the dairy one—to Washington. Senator Collins is going this month and I will be going subsequently. The ambassador, as you know, has been making fairly high profile representations on this matter. That is our No. 1 focus for this year.

Senator Boswell asked whether there will be more subsidies before 1 July. We expect there will be more subsidised exports under existing programs. The thing we have most sought to do is achieve a circumstance where there will be no further announcements of dairy export subsidies before 1 July, following on that most unwelcome round that was recently declared, about which we spoke earlier, Senator Boswell, and about which the industry made representations. As a result of our representations and those of the industry, we think there is a high probability that there will be no more. Mr Rowley and others from the dairy industry have not been able to obtain categorical assurances that there will be no further allocations. My personal view is that the industry in the United States would like them. I suspect that for budget and administrative reasons the odds are that there will not be any, but I can give no guarantee.

Under EEP there is continuing pressure in the United States to proceed on export enhancement programs and to move it after the Uruguay Round to a market support program. That would be a concern, but at least the size of it will be constrained by the Uruguay Round agreements. Each year the extent to which there are subsidies available will be constrained by the limits negotiated from now until the end of the century through the Uruguay Round—not sufficient limits, but a very good start. So, over the years, as ABARE and other assessments have made clear, there will be improved access for Australian products to those global markets. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I draw the minister's attention to a story on the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald which claims that within the next year two million Australian drivers will have to pay up to $350 each to convert their car airconditioners so that they can use non-ozone depleting refrigerants instead of CFCs. Could the minister advise the Senate as to whether these claims are correct or not?

—I have seen the article to which Senator Forshaw refers in his question. It seems to me, unfortunately, that the article has been crafted to cause very unnecessary alarm. Let me first say that the headline of the article to which Senator Forshaw refers—that is, that two million Australians will have to pay up to $350 each within the next year to convert their car airconditioners—is categorically incorrect.

PARA.TAB: It is well known that the manufacture and import of CFCs, apart from those needed for essential uses, will cease on 31 December 1995. This is consistent with the requirements of the Montreal protocol. CFCs have already been phased out in many industry sectors, including aerosols and refrigeration. The car airconditioning sector has in fact been one of the last to change.

The Sydney Morning Herald article implies that all car owners will have to convert their car airconditioners in the next year. This is untrue. People with systems operating well can keep using them as long as they want to. There is no legal requirement for car airconditioners to be changed over to an alternative refrigerant by the end of the year. I stress that people do not have to rush out and convert their airconditioning equipment. But in the future when people need to have their equipment serviced, they might find that CFC is becoming either unavailable or very expensive. That is why the EPA is advising car owners to replace their car airconditioner gas with one of the new ozone-benign alternatives at the next major service.If they have it converted as part of routine servicing I have been advised that this will cost no more than $100 extra. This is because most parts are changed in a major service due to normal wear and tear.

The Environment Protection Agency will conduct a public awareness campaign and a program to assist auto mechanics to provide accurate information to car owners. Australia's actions in phasing out CFCs are part of a global commitment under the Montreal protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer. The phase-out of all ozone depleting substances has the support of Commonwealth, state and territory governments. It has the support of industry and it has the support of the community. There are already signs that the Montreal protocol controls are starting to slow the rate of stratospheric ozone destruction. I am sure that will please all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is it true that there is a plan to expand the woodchip exports from Tasmania from the present approximately 2.9 million tonnes to 4 million tonnes? Given that we are constantly told that only waste material, not suitable for sawn timber, is used for woodchips, can the minister assure the Senate that there are markets for the more than 25 per cent increase in sawn timber which this expansion would imply—in other words, an additional 275,000 tonnes of sawn timber? Can the minister tell the Senate where this additional sawn timber will be sold, or will we simply see logs suitable for sawn timber being diverted in even greater numbers into chips to meet the increased export requirement?
—That is a matter that is outside my portfolio and it is a matter that should be properly directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources.

—With that response I remind you that I am seeking an indication of whether the woodchip exports are being derived from waste timber or not. We want to know: is it waste timber that is going into these woodchips or is it some other form of timber? I thought the minister for the environment would be able to answer that—which is the thrust of the question.

—I am only willing to answer questions directed to me as the minister for the environment that go to my own portfolio responsibilities. I think all senators are aware that woodchip exports are derived from both integrated logging operations and from sawmill residues. That is no secret. I believe that all senators and many people in the general community are well aware of that. As I have said on many occasions, the government's approach on this issue is that we are striving to find a balance between protecting the environment in this country and protecting the jobs of Australian workers. That has been a commitment we have held to for a long period. We will be advancing this issue within that framework.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I ask: what stage has been reached by the working group of technical experts under the steering committee of ANZECC and the Australian Forestry Council in formulating recommendations on broad criteria on which to base reserve systems to protect the nature conservation values of forests? In particular, is this process so advanced that it will be possible to have in place a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system to protect old-growth forest and wilderness values by the end of 1995? If not, why not, and when will such an inadequate reserve system be established?

—The working group that Senator Chamarette refers to has been making what can only be described as very slow progress. It is true that the New South Wales government and New South Wales representatives on that particular working group have not supported the publication of the work that has been done to date by the so-called Janis working group.

PARA.TAB: I can say that, for the Commonwealth's part, we are very committed to seeing the establishment of a forest reserve system. We are very committed, as I have said in the past, to seeing a forest reserve system that is comprehensive, adequate and representative. I can say that we have been concerned about the lack of progress between the states and the government, that is, the Janis group, which has been developing the criteria for the comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

In view of the difficulty in achieving agreement through the mechanism that is envisaged in the national forest policy statement, the Commonwealth does intend to develop its own position on CAR criteria to stimulate the policy debate and to move it forward. In fact, my own department has done substantial work to provide a basis for discussion on the CAR criteria within the Commonwealth by the development of a draft working paper.

I can say as far as the Commonwealth is concerned—and I believe this is a principle that is shared by state governments—that a CAR reserve system will form an integral part of regional forest agreements. These agreements to be negotiated between the Commonwealth and the states will be aimed at striking a balance between a range of economic and environmental obligations that both tiers of government have regarding the management and protection of forests.

As I said in answer to Senator Bell's supplementary question, I can confirm with you, Senator, that we are committed as we progress this work to the development of a very balanced approach—to balance the interests of both conservation and those who work in the forestry sector. I can assure you that the establishment of a genuinely comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system is very high on the agenda of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I ask: how does the current rapid assessment process fit with these provisions of the NFPS? What criteria are being used to assess the values of the areas being assessed under the rapid assessment process?

—The criteria in relation to the assessment process have now been made public in announcements made by government over the period of the last four weeks. They are in the public arena. I am fairly confident that Senator Chamarette is well aware, as are many others, of the approach that government is taking. I can say to Senator Chamarette that cabinet is meeting again today to look at a certain number of coupes. When the Prime Minister made his original statement, it was made clear that there would be an eight-week period. At the conclusion of that eight-week period of assessment, final decisions will be made in relation to those 509 coupes that have been identified in the past. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In the recently tabled Auditor-General's report on financial statement audits, the Auditor-General identified the following breaches at official establishments, otherwise known as the Lodge and Kirribilli House: 79 breaches of law where casual staff were paid from petty cash; 12 breaches of law of no employee declaration forms being completed—in other words, no tax was paid on their behalf; 26 breaches of issuing no group certificates; and 26 breaches of no employer superannuation contributions being made. Can the minister confirm that all of these breaches occurred at the Lodge or Kirribilli House and arose out of a dereliction of duty by the Prime Minister, who is responsible for both establishments?
—Yes, he sits there and issues the tax stamps.

—You might think that this a very funny thing, but others do not. Can the minister explain what is actually going on in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in relation to these matters or does it use the same accountant as Mr Keating used when he failed to lodge his own personal tax return some years ago?
—It is manifestly absurd to suggest that the Prime Minister personally should have any practical responsibility for the preparation of returns of that kind.
—Like Menzies.

—I am sure, as Senator Ray is saying, that Sir Robert Menzies, John Gorton, Harold Holt, Billy McMahon and Malcolm Fraser sat there doing their audit returns and chasing the paper trail for the overtime or whatever by kitchen hands! That is a manifestly absurd proposition and one does not have to have much understanding of the nature of one's public responsibilities to acknowledge that. Beyond that, I have no further information on the particular matters to which Senator Knowles refers. I will seek such information.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Prime Minister cannot take ultimate responsibility for his own department, who can? Companies and individuals who fail to comply with such reporting procedures are subject to prosecution and very hefty penalties. Will you give the Senate a solemn assurance that these breaches will be taken seriously and subject to independent advice as to whether prosecution should be brought against those responsible? If not, why not?
—There is nothing in what I have heard so far to suggest that these would be appropriate matters for prosecution. Beyond that, I have nothing further to add to my previous answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Shipping of Essential Supplies to Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. The minister would be aware that for the second time in the 25 years that I have been in Australia the road links between Western Australia and the rest of the continent have been cut. Cyclone Bobby is the instigator on this occasion. Can the minister advise the Senate what action the government is taking to increase the capacity for international carriers to be used for the shipping of essential supplies, the delivery of which is being disrupted due to the difficulties with land access? What measures are being put in place to ensure that those essential supplies can be brought into and out of Western Australia?

—I thank Senator McKiernan, a senator from Western Australia, for his question. It is true that the government is very keen to ensure that maximum opportunities exist for goods to be shipped into and out of Western Australia during this time of difficulty with both the Eyre Highway and the railway link cut or severely restricted. In the last two or three days representations have been made to me as customs minister by industry and the finance minister, Mr Beazley, in particular on what we can do to assist.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence, a special arrangement has been made to allow international carriers to be used for shipping supplies into and out of Western Australia. Normally, when the Department of Transport and Communications allows foreign vessels to carry domestic cargo, there is a 10 per cent limit of the vessel's deadweight tonnage before the vessel is regarded by customs to be on a domestic voyage. This means that there is scope for vessels on an international voyage to carry some domestic cargo without becoming liable for excise duty on the fuel used.

Whilst other forms of transport are not available to Western Australia, the government has agreed to waive the 10 per cent rule in assessing duty liable. The waiver applies only where the department of transport has issued a single voyage permit allowing foreign vessels to carry domestic cargo into and out of Western Australia and where an Australian ship is not available. This will hopefully alleviate some of the isolation that Western Australia is currently experiencing and assist in minimising disruption to commercial activity.

I am advised that it is possible that it may still be some time before the transcontinental railway link is re-established. These special arrangements will be available only whilst the transcontinental railway link is non-operational. The situation will be reviewed on a daily basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to the West Indies cricket broadcast fiasco, which is still not resolved with the series only a few days away. Why has this government switched sides from supporting the Nine Network, which it did two weeks ago, to then siding with the pay TV operator against the interests of Australian free to air viewers. Is it true that flip-flopping Minister Lee's current position is to advocate a simultaneous broadcast on free to air and pay TV, claiming that this is a one-off and will not set a precedent? How can the minister claim this when the ABA's preliminary advice is that Australis pay TV did not purchase the rights prior to gazettal of the free to air list and that the anti-siphoning provisions therefore still apply?
—There needs to be a question from our backbench to the Minister representing the Attorney-General as to whether Mr Packer has to disclose you lot as a wholly owned subsidiary or not.
—They would not be an asset.

—I thank Senator Bolkus for his advice that at least he would not have to list them as an asset. The government remains firmly committed to ensuring the continued availability of major sporting events free to the public on free to air television. The parliament's clear intention in the Broadcasting Services Act has been to ensure that sport does not migrate from free to air to pay television. But, in Australia, governments do not dictate what television stations have to broadcast.
—Why didn't they televise from Pakistan or New Zealand?

—As Senator Ray has correctly pointed out by interjection, there is nothing the government can do to guarantee that important overseas sporting events will be available on free to air. The last Australian overseas cricket competition had no pay TV but it was not telecast because Channel 9 and the other networks decided it was not commercially viable to do so, which they are entitled to do.

PARA.TAB: In the main, in the past when Australian teams have travelled to the West Indies, apart from the last occasion, I cannot recall a time when there has been television coverage. That is a great pity. The ultimate decision is a commercial decision for the networks. This is a one-off because of the claim, which may ultimately be validated because the final decision of the Broadcasting Authority has not yet been brought in, that this might be an exception to the anti-siphoning provision because of Australis's claim that it bought the rights before the anti-siphoning rules came in. If it did, then there is no way that the Commonwealth would or should retrospectively acquire them or take them away from it if they were bought in accordance with the law.

Other networks have shown some interest in free to air rights. The minister and I hope that one of the networks will come forward with an appropriate arrangement that will make this important series available. Given the results last night in Barbados, things are looking a bit encouraging. It would be a pity if we did not get a chance to see the series.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The position is that this series is now upon us. When is this Windies pay TV broadcast fiasco going to be resolved? Minister, are you going to stand by your government's promise that its anti-siphoning list will ensure that people will not have to pay for major events that they now see for free? When you brought out the anti-siphoning list, that is what you promised. Are you going to stick with that?
—Yes, Mr President.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Frequent Flier Points for Members of Parliament

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Over the weekend the minister would have seen media reports claiming that the use of frequent flier points by members of parliament was a rort. Can the minister please explain the basis for the decision to allow the use of frequent flier points? Does this benefit the Commonwealth government and the taxpayer? If so, how?

—I thank Senator West for her question. I think the concern implicit in her question would be shared by senators from all sides. When I was Minister for Administrative Services, I had representations from senators from all sides, none of them saying, `Please, sir, can I travel a bit more? I am not travelling enough.' I do not remember any senator ever saying that—let alone the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I think it would be the world's most unlikely suggestion that he would be desperately in search of another trip somewhere.

PARA.TAB: Senators were frustrated that they were continually advised that they had these frequent flier entitlements, accumulated by fares paid for by the taxpayers, which they could use to fund the proper discharge of their parliamentary duties, but the existing rules did not allow them to use them. I had representations from the opposition and from the government; I am not sure whether I had any from the minor parties, but the position consistently applies equally to all the parties.

Therefore, we started a review as to how we could use this benefit—instead of just handing this right purchased by the taxpayers back to the airlines—without exposing it to any misuse. That matter was not resolved by the time I finished being Minister for Administrative Services, but I understand that the new minister, as of 1 January, has put in place an arrangement to which, on the basis of formal advice from both the Attorney-General's Department and the Remuneration Tribunal, there is no impediment. On the face of it, and as far as I can see from the study which I have done, it will actually save the taxpayers money. Rather than costing them money, it will actually save them money.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—Everybody but you understands, Senator. But thank you for giving me the opportunity to explain. Trips that would otherwise have been funded by taxpayers under existing Remuneration Tribunal entitlements will be funded by frequent flier points made available by the airlines. The use is intended to be very heavily regulated and proscribed so that it is for government purposes—for parliamentary and official purposes—in accordance with entitlements set down by the independent Remuneration Tribunal and the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. In fact, it is designed to save the taxpayers money, and I think that it will. We will be continuing to monitor it to ensure that it does.

PARA.TAB: Rather than criticising the government for using frequent flier points, thus saving the taxpayers money, it should be realised that we would have been open to some criticism if we failed to do it. We have sought to proceed very cautiously because it is open to misunderstanding, which has been proved by the publicity on Sunday. From all the evidence I can see, I think that the minister has safeguarded this proposal so that we can save the money without the potential for abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware that on 22 December last year a stocktake carried out by the asset management division at the Salisbury DSTO found that 146 items had vanished from the guidance weapons in the avionics technology division? Is the minister aware that these items include 14 computers; nine printers; 15 monitors; five disk drives; 13 saws, sanders and lathes; 7 milling machines; photocopiers; microwaves; a hydraulic mobile crane; microscopes; an office safe; several typewriters; a boring machine; a drilling machine; a fax machine; a laser; several welders; and even an entire vacuum encapsulation plant? How many of the missing items have been returned? Given my revelations last week about the theft of gold supplies by DSTO employees over many years, what does this further information say about the integrity of internal security at the highly sensitive DSTO? Will the minister initiate a full independent review and audit of the DSTO at Salisbury?

—Senator Chapman refers to two sets of inquiries which form one inquiry because they came from the same individual who made allegations about missing gold and other equipment. The Inspector-General has been involved in investigating it. One of the difficulties he has pointed out to us in terms of security at Salisbury is the absolute disparate nature of the buildings and their closeness to car parks, which makes security a nightmare. Most of these problems will be solved by the new consolidation program, of which Senator Chapman would be aware.

PARA.TAB: I have looked at some of the issues, such as the computers. It was found that in many cases computer parts were taken by the employees on the basis that they were trade-ins for new computers and that the people who credited them for the trade-in did not want to take them. Nevertheless, the Inspector-General has found that security has been a problem at Salisbury for 40 years. Forty years of problems have not been properly reported up the chain. When there was a crackdown in 1992 by management—it was long overdue, because management was complicit in some of these practices—again, there was not proper compliance. Hence, we had the Inspector-General's investigation and the various recommendations to tighten up security that are currently being implemented.

Senator Chapman asks whether this issue warrants an independent inquiry. I am quite satisfied with the extent and breadth of the inquiries of the Inspector-General and the conclusions he has come up with. I have not yet seen anything that warrants a further inquiry. It warrants the strongest possible action to make sure that past practices, not all of which are outright theft—a lot of it is seen as freebies for friends, management, visitors or whatever—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all right, is it?

—I am not condoning those practices to any extent, but they are not prosecutable under the law, because there was some degree of endorsement by management and poor record keeping that make prosecution impossible in this case. Those areas—record keeping and practices—need to be looked at, and that is what DSTO has under way at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to a report in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald that the minister is pushing for more funds for the Badgerys Creek airport. I ask: is this latest move an admission that Badgerys Creek has only ever been planned as an overflow airport, which would not alleviate the noise burden caused by the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? Would this plan finally make Badgerys Creek a real alternative to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? What regulatory mechanisms will the minister use to divert domestic and international flights to Badgerys Creek, as reported in this article, or will this be left entirely to market forces?

—The Minister for Transport has already publicly responded to most of the points that Senator Bourne has raised, particularly the one about what regulatory mechanisms will be used in respect of traffic going to KSA or to what is to be called Sydney West. The Minister for Transport announced on 4 May 1994 that the development of Sydney's new airport at Badgerys Creek will be accelerated with the construction of a runway capable of handling major scheduled aircraft operations. It is planned that a new 2,900-metre runway suitable for the use of large jet aircraft will be commissioned in 1998-99. This runway will be suitable for all domestic operations and international medium-haul operations for destinations such as Tokyo, Seoul, Bangkok, Hong Kong and Honolulu.

PARA.TAB: The decision last year to construct the 2,900-metre runway has made Badgerys Creek a very real alternative to KSA. The new Sydney West airport will help meet the rapidly growing demand for scheduled air services to the Sydney region and assist in the economic development of the western Sydney region. The airport will provide the capacity to alleviate any peak period congestion at KSA.

Work has recently been completed on a review of the airport master plan and preparation of a new concept design, cost estimates and implementation program for the development. The results of this work are now being incorporated into an evaluation of alternative arrangements for the construction and future operations of the new airport.

The Commonwealth is working with the New South Wales government on the provision of adequate land transport links to the new airport to ensure that passengers and freight can be moved efficiently. An EIS on options for the national highway between Prestons and Cecil Park, for which the Minister for Transport has pledged $200 million, has commenced and work is already under way on an engineering study to identify a rail corridor to Sydney West airport.

Sydney West airport will be curfew free and offer 24-hour operations. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Given the environmental damage that can result from mismanagement of hazardous waste and the importance that our regional trading partners place upon Australia fulfilling its obligations under the Basel convention, can the minister inform the Senate whether the government has any plans to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act?

—Australia signed the Basel convention on the control of trans-boundary movements of hazardous wastes and their disposal in 1992. Existing Commonwealth legislation fails to meet our obligations under the Basel convention and last week the government decided to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989.

PARA.TAB: The amendments will ensure that Australian exports of hazardous wastes are managed in an environmentally sound manner. Currently, the act regulates only imports and exports of hazardous wastes that have no value—that is, wastes intended for final disposal. The amendments will extend regulation to trade in hazardous wastes destined for recycling and recovery operations. These changes will provide greater certainty to industry and meet our international obligations under the Basel convention.

Most of Australia's trading partners have become parties to the Basel convention. They have asked Australia to notify them of proposed exports of hazardous wastes, as is required by the convention. The amendments to the act will enable the government to ensure that this is done.

In proceeding to amend the act, the government has consulted very extensively with both industry and NGOs. A policy reference group has been formed to give continuing advice. An expert technical group is being formed to advise the government on difficult and substantive questions—such as how to define a hazardous waste in law, how to distinguish between products and wastes, and what level of contamination by hazardous constituents renders a waste hazardous. This takes into account concerns that have been raised by industry that appropriate consultation should be undertaken before the act is amended.

Signatories to the Basel convention generally agree that hazardous waste should be treated at home whenever possible. Australian policy is that such wastes should be exported for final disposal only under exceptional circumstances, and this policy will now be explicit in the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 1 March Senator O'Chee asked me a question about magnetic resonance imaging. I would like to provide the Senate with some more information. The government's policy for promoting the provision of MRI services to Australians is based on the results of a comprehensive national assessment program. This assessment program was established as a joint Commonwealth-state initiative and conducted under the auspices of the National Health Technology Advisory Panel over the period 1986 to 1990. The resulting policy for funding MRI services responds to the concerns of the Commonwealth and state governments that complex and high cost technologies like MRI are introduced in a planned and cost-effective way. Accordingly, the policy targets subsidies to a set number of publicly owned MRI units via a grants program to states. Based on NHTAP's recommendations, a national supply target of 18 MRI units has been set to meet the needs of private, or non-compensable, patients and Medicare hospital patients mainly for neurological and neurosurgical applications.

PARA.TAB: Under the MRI program, the Commonwealth provides grants to the states for the purchase of MRI units and about 80 per cent of recurrent costs. State governments are responsible for locating the Medicare-funded units within major neurological centres and choosing the physical location of units. State governments provide the remaining 20 per cent of recurrent costs and are also able to purchase services from privately owned units. MRI is available at the designated units free of charge to private, or non-compensable, patients, hospital outpatients and Medicare hospital in-patients on the basis of a referral by a specialist. In 1994-95 the Commonwealth's contribution to the cost of the MRI program will be $21.5 million.

In Queensland, Medicare-funded units are located at the Royal Brisbane and the Princess Alexandra hospitals in Brisbane and at the Townsville Hospital. The Queensland government decided on the location of these units. Under the MRI program, states are able to purchase services from privately owned units. This provision enables states to ensure that patients who, for medical reasons, are unable to travel to the Medicare-funded units have access to MRI services. In the Northern Territory the state government purchases services from a private sector facility in Darwin in order to provide patients with access to MRI services.

A targeted grants program is considered a better funding approach than Medicare rebates for providing Australians with access to clinically appropriate and quality MRI services which are affordable to patients and the community while constraining the proliferation of a complex and potentially expensive technology.

To ensure the government's policy for funding MRI services responds to developments in the technology of MRI and its clinical use, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has asked the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee, AHTAC—NHTAP's successor body—to undertake a comprehensive review of MRI in Australia. AHTAC advice is being sought on a number of issues, including the accepted clinical role of MRI in the light of these developments and Australia's resulting needs for MRI services, including the number of units, their locational requirements and other measures to promote quality, appropriate and cost-effective use of the technology. AHTAC will be considering the matter of the review at its April 1995 meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Included among the missing items, as I detailed in my question to the minister, are: 14 computers, nine printers, 15 monitors, five disc drives, 13 saws, sanders, lathes, seven milling machines, as well as photocopiers, microwaves, a hydraulic mobile crane—

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting question. The minister excused it because he said that that car park was near the office building, but that is hardly an excuse for inadequate security.
—You would need a forklift.

—Perhaps a forklift has gone missing as well. The list continues: several typewriters, a boring machine, a drilling machine, a fax machine, a laser, several welders and even an entire vacuum encapsulation plant. About the only thing that is not on the missing assets list is a partridge in a pear tree. The minister said today in answering the question that he believed the existing investigation by the Inspector-General of Defence was adequate. I remind him, as I said earlier, that it has been known since 1991 that this unacceptable practice had been going on. Yet nothing had been done, until I raised the matter in parliament last week publicly, to take any action against those employees involved in this activity. Needless to say, I suspect that the list I have incorporated in Hansard today is only the tip of the iceberg. If an independent inquiry were launched, which the minister seems intent on resisting, we would find that much more has walked out the doors of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

PARA.TAB: The concern I have with this apparent practice of DSTO is that we are talking about one of Australia's most highly sensitive defence institutions. The DSTO has the responsibility of developing sophisticated weapons guidance systems, tactical electronics warfare components, defence communications and cryptographic research. It is disappointing that four years ago the minister failed to take effective, immediate steps to stamp out these abhorrent practices, which have come to be regarded as a part of the culture at DSTO for many years. The public has a right to expect that their defence institutions are properly managed and secure, but the evidence to date suggests this is far from the case. One wonders what information may have been on the computers which disappeared from the guidance weapons division and the avionics division at Salisbury.

I am not convinced that the existing inquiry is adequate. This represents a serious threat to Australia's national security. The fact that computers and disk drives have mysteriously vanished from DSTO is a primary concern and should be the subject of an independent inquiry—at least independent from the minister and independent from the defence department. The potential for a cover-up within the department is certainly a major concern. It is frightening that these dishonest practices can be passed off as part of DSTO culture. What else is part of its culture—selling defence secrets to our potential enemies? With the dishonesty exhibited in this situation, this is highly likely. Without an open and frank inquiry, we simply do not know the answer to these questions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Knowles this day, relating to findings in Auditor-General Audit Report No. 22 of 1994-95 concerning the Lodge and Kirribilli House.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it particularly disturbing that the minister could actually say in answer to the supplementary question that there appears to be no real evidence of a need for prosecution from what has happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said from what I heard you say so far.

—Okay, from what you have heard I have said so far. What I listed at question time, Senator Evans, was the whole list of 143 breaches committed by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in terms of simple things such as failure to remit income tax instalment, failure to issue group certificates, failure to pay superannuation productivity benefits and casual staff wages paid from petty cash. If people in the private sector had actually done that, they would be subject to prosecution and, as I said before, hefty penalties.

PARA.TAB: The situation remains constant that this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) can consistently skirt around all of these things. It does not matter whether or not it is his own personal income tax return that he fails to lodge, whether it is that of his piggery or anything else. It matters not to this Prime Minister. In the Auditor-General's report, under the `Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: This section details the results of the ANAO audit into irregularities concerning minor expenditure, including the payment of wages from petty cash to casual staff, at the Lodge and Kirribilli House (the Official Establishments) and the action taken to rectify the irregularities.
Surely these irregularities should not be occurring in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The report continues:
This matter was raised in the press in August 1994 where it was alleged that the payment of wages from petty cash was highly irregular and in contravention of section 70AH of the Audit Act 1901.
As I say, that is not the only thing that has been found to be irregular. The report also states:

Casual staff are employed to assist with catering for large functions, as well as to fill vacancies pending permanent filling of positions. Before mid-1994, casual staff were paid wages from petty cash, no employee declaration forms were completed, no tax was paid on their behalf or group certificates issued, and no employer superannuation contribution payments were made.

This is simply and utterly not acceptable, coming as it does from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and from institutions such as the Lodge and Kirribilli House. We need to be reminded that it was those staff members at the Lodge who were dismissed without any reason whatsoever. If that too had happened in the private sector, then there would have been very serious questions asked. But for some reason this Prime Minister seems to be able to get away with all of these things and get off scot-free.

PARA.TAB: The report notes that the investigation revealed that the press reports were accurate. The report states that the department's administrative procedural manual included in its definition of petty cash expenditure:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . expenditure not exceeding $100 in respect of any single purchase or service. Cash payments to casual employees or cash payments for supplies for the Official Establishments are exempt from this definition.
The report goes on to say:

This definition conflicted with the requirements of section 70AH of the Audit Act, which prohibits payments to employees in cash unless otherwise determined by the Minister for Finance. Such a determination had not been obtained.

The issue is that this Prime Minister seems to be able to go about things willy-nilly. At the end of the day, he has to be held responsible for something. The buck has to stop somewhere. Presumably the Prime Minister is ultimately responsible for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Where does the buck stop? Is this man prepared to take any responsibility? The report goes on to say:

The ANAO noted that during 1993-94 there had been nineteen petty cash reimbursements totalling about $43 000 for the Lodge and Kirribilli House. Casual staff wages included in these reimbursements totalled almost $10 000 in nearly 80 transactions.

This is not just a one-off thing. People might say that he may not have known that this was going on, but this was happening in the residences in which he lives and he attends the functions in those residences. Surely he should be aware of what is going on. The report also notes that two casuals had their day's wages retrospectively approved. The report further states:

The ANAO's examination also identified that there were no receipts for some household requisites. The ANAO recommended that receipts be obtained for all individual purchases from petty cash which exceeded $20.
The Department agreed with the recommendations and advised that the recommendation has been implemented to the extent that it is cost-effective to do so.
Who decides whether it is cost effective or not?

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans) this day, to a question without notice asked by Senator Ellison on 2 March, relating to the detention of Mr Eric Robert Bowra in the United Arab Emirates.

SPEECH.PARA: Up until last Friday, Robert Bowra was a prisoner in the United Arab Emirates. Mr Bowra had been imprisoned as a result of a collision between two boats. He was driving one boat which he was using to exhibit to the United Arab Emirates navy. He was doing that in the course of his employment. If this had happened in Australia he would not have been charged with any offence under our law. Nonetheless, we must respect the law of foreign countries. Under the law of the United Arab Emirates, he was accordingly convicted and sentenced to a term of 12 months imprisonment. That was reduced on 5 February 1995 to six months. However, notwithstanding the order of the court that he serve only six months, which expired on 6 February, he served another month before his release last Friday.

PARA.TAB: I want to place on record my congratulations for the efforts of Mr Philip Nixon, a business associate of Mr Bowra, who worked untiringly to secure his release and also pay tribute to the Bowra family and in particular Jenny Bowra, Rob Bowra's wife, who travelled to the United Arab Emirates in an effort to free her husband. This has been a trying time for the family. They have suffered personally, emotionally and financially. As I understand it, the business that Mr Bowra is involved in has suffered irretrievably and the human cost has been gigantic.

This serves as a lesson to the government that there are Australian citizens who travel to remote parts of the world in an effort to promote exports for this country and that, from time to time, through no fault of their own they may run foul of foreign laws. It is in that context that I put it to the government in the strongest terms that it has to stand by our citizens who go abroad and run into strife in these sorts of circumstances.

It is not unreasonable for any Australian to expect its government to stand by them in times of strife overseas. This was not your normal situation of a drug runner or someone who had committed a heinous crime overseas. It has to be distinguished greatly from that sort of situation. I say to the government and the people of Australia: let us learn from this lesson and ensure that in future this sort of situation does not happen again. This man was imprisoned whilst he had been granted bail. He was not released, even though a court order had granted him bail. He was kept beyond his sentence for a whole month and not released. I would submit that this is a clear instance where the government could use its full weight and make communications at the highest level.

Whilst I acknowledge that Senator Evans did write to the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the United Arab Emirates, I put it to the government that this could have been done at an earlier stage. I note that on the Today program on Channel 9, Peter Harvey, who is travelling with the Prime Minister, said that the Prime Minister was going to make representations in the United Arab Emirates in an endeavour to gain the release of this man. Of course, Mr Bowra was released last Friday. Either Mr Harvey got his facts wrong or he just was not aware of the situation. Maybe the Prime Minister had misled him or perhaps even the Prime Minister was not aware of the situation.

Nonetheless, this has been a most serious case. I believe it is one that we must learn from. The government must set in plan a future program for the effective assistance of Australian nationals who get into this sort of strife overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison has let his enthusiasm run away a little bit from the facts of the situation. The Australian government made its position very clear at the outset: while there are limitations to what we can do for ordinary Australian citizens who get in strife with the law in other countries in circumstances where that law is apparently being applied properly by its own standards, where it becomes apparent that there is something questionable about the application of that country's law we will respond very quickly with appropriate representations. That is what happened in this instance.
—It didn't happen with the bail. Not with the bail.

—Once it became apparent that there was a problem on the bail front, representations were made at an official level by our diplomatic representation based in Riyadh, and that was followed up by direct representations from me. It is always a matter of making a judgment in these cases as to whether or not your representations are going to be productive or whether they will simply be counterproductive in all the circumstances of the case. That is a matter which you just have to make case by case judgments about.

PARA.TAB: I believe we did everything possible in the circumstances of this matter to move it forward with results that I think are now evident. I am not sure at the end of the day what was the most influential factor—whether the ministerial representations did make any difference or whether it was simply a matter of the law of Abu Dhabi working itself out.

Throughout all of this, Australia continues to offer in these sorts of cases, whether or not we make extra representations, what consular advice and assistance we can to prisoners, whoever they are and whatever the state of play may be with the law of the country in

SPEECH.PARA: question and its observance in that case. We did that in the form of basic consular assistance with Mr Bowra right from the beginning.

PARA.TAB: As to the Prime Minister's willingness to take this matter up, there were only very limited options available to him not least because he was only stopping in Dubai, not in Abu Dhabi. There is a completely different legal system basically in operation in the two emirates. He was nonetheless going to ask the ambassador to convey his concern about the situation to the authorities in Abu Dhabi when our ambassador met them tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that was only after I asked the question, Senator. That is the truth.
—Only because we had not been aware until last week that he had not been released as was promised to be the case.
—But for three weeks he had been inside.

—Okay, you made a hero of yourself, Senator Ellison. That is fine. I am delighted for Mr Bowra that you were working on his behalf and all the rest of it. I just do not want you to be unfair in the aspersions you cast upon the government. There is only so much we can do for Australian citizens who get themselves in strife overseas. There seems to be a belief around the place that governments are absolutely omnipotent in terms of our capacity not only to be aware of all these situations and every one of their ins and outs but also to make a difference as to the way in which people are dealt with. Our hands are remarkably tied in these situations. There are very limited things we can do. Often when we do seek to make representations in circumstances where a matter of sensitivity is involved, it can be counterproductive unless those representations are extremely carefully handled.

PARA.TAB: I became officially aware only this morning when a cable arrived—Senator Ellison might have heard earlier than that—that he had been released. By this stage, the Prime Minister was well on his way from Singapore to Dubai, and Mr Harvey had no doubt already filed his account of what was going to happen from Singapore. To be critical of the Prime Minister—as Senator Ellison was—the Prime Minister's staff or the government for not keeping people up to speed in that respect is, again, very unfair in all the circumstances. We were doing our best to keep track of a situation that clearly did need some attention. We gave it that attention. You have had a good result; now be gracious about it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
