TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend general business notice of motion No. 1316, standing in my name and relating to the shipment of radioactive plutonium waste.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —General business notice of motion No. 1316, as amended, now reads:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)with concern the current shipment of a container of glassified, highly radioactive plutonium waste which commenced its voyage from the French port of Cherbourg to Japan in late February 1995, and
(ii)that one of the favoured routes for this shipment is either through or adjacent to Australian waters; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Australian Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to indicate in the strongest possible manner that this nation will not accept the inherent dangers associated with shipments of plutonium or plutonium waste in our vicinity,
(ii)to push for a complete ban on this dangerous trade, and
(iii)to withdraw from the international plutonium economy by ceasing uranium exports to Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1316, as amended, standing in my name, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion to provide for the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1316 standing in the name of Senator Margetts for this day relating to the transportation of plutonium waste.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is this debate urgent? I think we should start with a quick re-statement of the hazards. This material is some of the most radioactive waste ever produced. A person standing one metre away from an unshielded glass block of plutonium waste would receive a fatal dose of radiation in one minute. An accident along the route—for example, an on-board fire—could be catastrophic. The first shipment will contain 28 glass blocks of plutonium waste. There are 3,000 such glass blocks waiting to be returned to Japan. Returning them all could take up to 100 shipments. How many will pass by Australia?

PARA.TAB: Why is this urgent? Many countries along the possible routes have, by now, either condemned or expressed concern at the shipment. They include Argentina, Indonesia, Ecuador, Brazil, South Africa, Chile, Fiji, the Philippines, the Caribbean community—CARICOM—Aruba and Dutch Antilles, Jamaica, Dominican Republic, British Virgin Islands, Honduras, Ethiopia, US Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Martinique, Federated States of Micronesia, Nauru and six members of the United States House of Representatives. Australia has not.

It has not opposed the 1992 Akatsuki Maru shipment despite widespread regional and international opposition. One of the favoured routes for this waste shipment is across the Indian Ocean and through the Tasman Sea. This route is highly likely for the exact reason that Australia has not opposed the shipment. We may then become the favourite route for future shipments. Waiting to win or lose this game of Russian roulette is not good enough. The next chamber is unlikely to be empty.

It is urgent because the question has to be asked: why won't the Australian government express its concern, given the obvious dangers involved and the fact that this could be the first of many such highly hazardous shipments? One of the reasons is obviously that we are compromised by our uranium sales to Japan. The bilateral agreement under which we sell uranium to Japan specifies those parts of the Japanese nuclear program in which Australian uranium can be used. This constitutes Australian approval of the program.

Under the 1982 agreement, it was agreed that the Japanese could send spent fuel containing Australian uranium to France and the United Kingdom to be reprocessed, and then take back the plutonium that was separated. This reprocessing contract between the French and the Japanese also specifies that the high level waste created by the reprocessing of spent fuel has to be returned to Japan. It is exactly this type of waste that may now pass close to Australia. (Quorum formed)

It is urgent because, whilst the current wastes do not arise from the reprocessing of Australian uranium, in a future shipment they could. Regardless, it is clear that by supporting the Japanese nuclear program—which includes the reprocessing of spent fuel and the creation of extremely hazardous plutonium wastes—Australia is complicit in this waste shipment and in others which may follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Margetts, your time has expired.
—That was not five minutes.
—Senator Margetts, I have watched the clock carefully. You certainly had your five minutes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the motion for the suspension of standing orders moved by Senator Margetts. We do not believe that this issue requires a special debate here in the Senate. At the moment this issue is obviously of some interest to people in the Australian community and internationally—and we recognise that. But the issues of concern that Senator Margetts wishes to express, we believe, can be expressed on any number of occasions in the Senate, without having to suspend standing orders at the present time.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the government, I point out we have been advised that the shipment of vitrified radioactive waste left Cherbourg for Japan aboard the British freighter Pacific Pintail on 23 February. The waste has resulted from the reprocessing of Japanese nuclear fuel in France to recover plutonium and uranium for recycling in Japan's nuclear energy program. The waste contains no usable plutonium or uranium and is not significant from a nuclear non-proliferation perspective. So we want to make it clear that we do not see the issues raised by Senator Margetts or her level of concern with them, which she has expressed in her motion and in the five-minute speech she has just made, as a real threat—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the waste going back or is it the plutonium for re-use?

—The plutonium that is going back is not usable; it is vitrified. As I am advised, it is in a vitrified form. That means, as I understand it, it is not able to be re-used for other purposes. The concern that is being raised by Senator Margetts we do not believe is—
—Does that make sense? It is going back for re-use, though, isn't it?

—A shipment of vitrified radioactive waste is going back. The waste has resulted from the reprocessing of Japanese nuclear fuel in France to recover plutonium and uranium for recycling in Japan's nuclear energy program. It is vitrified to make it safer, not in the way Senator Margetts is raising it here as a concern to the Australian community. Certainly we want to point out that this ship will not pass through any of Australia's territorial waters—
—How do you know that?
—The Japanese have made it clear that it will not be going through our territorial waters.
—When?

—That is the advice I have received; our territorial waters cover a 200-mile zone around Australia. I am advised that that ship will not be going through our territorial waters; it will stay in international waters which, of course, are open to international shipping.

PARA.TAB: I conclude on the point that, whatever concerns Senator Margetts may obviously and sincerely believe in, we believe that they can be expressed at appropriate times in general debate in this place as well as in such forums as the adjournment debate, without at the moment having to suspend the standing orders so that this item can be brought on specially. So we ask the Senate to reject the suspension of standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, I perhaps should explain to you that, when a quorum is called in a suspension, the clock keeps ticking. So you had the full five minutes but you did not have the full five minutes as speaking time.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Perhaps the Senate will realise that I did not call the quorum and might at some stage allow me my other 2 1/2 minutes, by leave.

—Senator Margetts does not really expect a full debate on this matter at the moment. It is a technique, and a useful one, to lift the profile of a particular issue, and she has taken the half an hour opportunity to do so. She knows, as well as any other senator, that these matters can be debated in general business. The Greens get two seventy-sixths of the time available, and I do not think they have had an item of general business for some time, although I might be mistaken on that. But that is the correct time for debate of these matters.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the opposition, we think the matters that are the subject of the substance of the issue, as far as they relate to the international transport of radioactive materials, are a worthy subject for consideration by this chamber. It may not be that it is of immediacy if, as the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) says, this particular transport is not crossing Australia's 200-mile limit.

However, I think there is a public concern at the moment as to the need for assurances on the proper safe handling of radioactive material. There is also, I think, some public confusion as to the status of this material. Senator Schacht said it is in a vitrified form—and, presumably, it is put in that form for better safety in travel. I am not sure exactly how that works if the plutonium then has to be recovered from it in order to be burnt in the reactors in Japan. But certainly the public are entitled to know that, and they are entitled to know exactly what safety assurances the Australian government can give.

So at an appropriate time it would seem to me to be a very sensible subject for this chamber to consider. It would give us the opportunity to listen to the government's assurances as to how it does protect Australia's interests in these matters. Even if it is not appropriate on this occasion, I am sure that there will be an occasion in the future when such a shipment does intrude upon Australia's zone, and that will be of direct interest to the Australian people.

Later on in the amended motion of Senator Margetts, she raises the whole issue of the nuclear fuel cycle and reiterates the opposition of the Greens to that. I think in some ways that is a bit unfortunate because it tends to blur the issue. That debate is one that has been had many times over the years; the debate that I have not heard many times is the one concerning international transport of these materials.

Chances are that we will find there will be an increasing number of these transports as nuclear fuel is reprocessed and moved back to source reactors. Also, there are the obligations that were mentioned by Senator Schacht to take back the waste from such reprocessing. The safety of such transport is obviously a matter of concern to the international community and a matter of concern to the Australian community. The Australian people would want to be assured that the Australian government is satisfied—and they would want to know the basis on which it was satisfied—that the transport of that waste is not something that is dangerous.

I personally look forward to the opportunity for that debate to take place. We in the coalition have, I guess, demonstrated our bona fides in this debate by raising issues of concern about the transport of low level waste within Australia and whether it is being transported in a safe way, a way that gives confidence to the Australian people, and also whether it is being stored in a safe way. Our criticism of the Australian government for failing to put in place its permanent repository for this low level waste, waste that is already in Australia, is well known. We are looking for the Senate, through its committee process, to have a look again at the issue of low level waste in Australia and the storage of that waste.

But this motion by Senator Margetts relates to high level radioactive material being transported across the world in shipping. I think the safety regime that has been developed by the international community is something that should be debated at an appropriate time in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —We, the Australian Democrats, support the suspension of orders because we think this is a very important issue. After having heard both Senator Schacht and Senator Hill, I am rather alarmed at their evident lack of understanding of the very important aspects of the nuclear fuel cycle which underlie this motion. For the edification of those two senators, I point out that the fuel which is used in a nuclear reactor consists of uranium 235 and uranium 238. The uranium 235 is the less common element. It is the one which is fissionable. The process of enrichment increases the concentration up to a point where that fuel can be used. But, inevitably, a lot of uranium 238 is carried into the nuclear reactor. It is that uranium 238 which is then transmuted in the reactor into plutonium 239 and higher isotopes of plutonium.

PARA.TAB: When the fuel comes out of the reactor, a very wide range of radioactive materials is present. There are present some very short half-life, very intense radioactive substances; mid-term radioactive substances, like strontium 90 and caesium 137 with half-lives of 28 and 30 years respectively; very long-lived isotopes, such as plutonium 239 with a half-life of 24,000 years; and higher isotopes which have variable half-lives but generally very long half-lives.

The practice of treating this material is to leave it in cooling ponds for anything from three or four months up to several years while those short half-life materials decay. Then it is sent off, if it can be, for reprocessing. In the reprocessing we attempt to remove the remaining uranium 235 and plutonium 239, which can be used as fuels either for nuclear power stations or indeed for weapons, and we attempt to sequester the medium-term materials—the strontium 90, caesium 137 and that class of things with half-lives measured in tens of years—and the longer half-life materials, like the higher isotopes of plutonium, americium and a whole range of others which have very long half-lives. It is that material which is then perhaps placed in glass. In this case the French have placed it in glass. It is an attempt to render that material safer.

I think that is the real point at issue: how safe is this material with these very long half-lives which is being transported more than halfway round the world, from France to Japan? I think there is considerable evidence that it is not particularly safe. I say to Senator Hill that there is no intention to extract it back out of the glass and use it as fuel at all. It is sequestered because it poses a danger, and there is an attempt here to put it into a material which makes it safe.

However, some work in Adelaide which goes back a number years shows that these radioactive elements which are alpha remitters—that is, they emit very high energy particles—being contained in glass in fact leads to the quite rapid breakdown of this glass and the release of the radioactive elements. It was precisely this sort of observation that led to people at the Australian National University looking at the process of incorporating these in a rock-like material—the so-called synroc process. But, unfortunately, synroc is subject to exactly the same breakdown process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have been listening intently to Senator Coulter, and not once have I heard him try to convince us of the urgency of this debate, which is what he is supposed to be debating. He seems to be debating the basic question.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I think there is a general agreement among the gentlemen in this chamber that, as we are limiting contributions to five minutes, one can range reasonably widely in that five minutes to deal with the issues, which means that the substantive issue can be mentioned.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I think there is some merit in what Senator Macdonald had to say but there is also some merit in what Senator Coulter had to say. As there are only a few seconds left in Senator Coulter's speech, I ask him to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important point is that these materials, if they are lost at sea, pose a very long-term hazard—not just to this generation but to many future generations. There is a real chance of this happening. Glassification is not a safe technique. Therefore, as this shipment is now travelling across the ocean—I come back to the original point—it is important that this matter be dealt with now.

—I rise to complete some of the points that Senator Margetts was unable to make regarding the urgency of this debate and the reasons for it to be held and to also reply to some of the comments that have been made previously, possibly in ignorance. Firstly, Senator Schacht assured the Senate that material in the vitrified form is safer material. I presume he meant that we therefore do not have an urgent or important matter before us. I repeat something that Senator Margetts said: a person standing one metre away from an unshielded glass block of plutonium waste—or the vitrified waste, as Senator Schacht called it—would receive a fatal dose of radiation in one minute. An accident along the route involving, say, an on board fire could be catastrophic.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht also reassured us that the ship in question would not be going through our territorial waters but would stay in international waters. But the question that makes this issue very important is: who will be liable for costs of rescue in the eventuality of an accident or misadventure? The reason for the urgency of debate of this matter is the fact that the ship's route is currently being decided—whether it is to go via Cape Horn or across the Indian Ocean and through the Tasman Sea. This latter route would bring the ship, if not into our territorial waters, clearly within the vicinity. In the same way we could be held responsible for rescuing people in misadventure, we could be liable for the operations that might be involved in the case of an accident.

It is very important that this parliament understand that this issue is going on and make a statement about it. It would have been highly desirable to get a formal motion from the Senate but, in the absence of that, it is imperative to raise the issue. While we are grateful for the five minutes that we are each being allowed to debate this matter, this issue is clearly much more important than that time allows. It is urgent because, even though the current wastes do not arise from the reprocessing of Australian uranium, a future shipment well could. It is really important that we realise that by supporting the Japanese nuclear program, which includes the reprocessing of spent fuel and creation of extremely hazardous plutonium waste, Australia is complicit in this waste shipment and in the others which may follow. We believe that there will be an alternation of wastes with actual plutonium being sent.

Could we oppose the shipment? That would be very difficult. The consent which Australia gave Japan in 1982 to use our uranium was advanced generic consent—that is, it was blanket consent, not case by case. It is unclear how Australia could rescind that consent, especially since the details of how this could be done are contained in so-called administrative arrangements which are secret. The government claims to have regular consultations with the Japanese government concerning the bilateral agreement, but the details of these consultations are available again to only a select few. It is very important that these be raised.

Even if it were legally possible to rescind Australia's consent to these shipments, or any other aspect of the Japanese nuclear program, commercial reality would be likely to stand in the way. Japan is Australia's biggest export market for uranium. If we were to oppose the Japanese nuclear program now, the Japanese would probably go elsewhere for supplies—especially given the glut of cheap uranium on world markets. With the Australian uranium industry already operating at well below capacity, such a loss would probably be fatal. So do not hold your breath: once again, the profits of uranium companies will receive higher priority than Australia's environment and the health of its people.

Senator Hill implied that that was not relevant, but it clearly is. Ironically, the government claims that by selling uranium we are having a positive influence on the international nuclear industry. But this episode clearly reveals that the opposite is true. Uranium sales compromise our ability to speak freely on nuclear matters as our stance on a given issue must take commercial considerations into account. Thus, despite the clear threat that this shipment of plutonium waste could pose to the Australian environment and population, the federal government still stands shamefully mute. It is urgent that a full debate on this issue take place. It is regrettable that at this point a mere superficial garnering of the arguments is able to be presented to show to the Senate that it is a matter of great urgency. It would have been good to continue with the motion that my colleague Senator Margetts presented.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General which was presented to the President after the last sitting of the Senate pursuant to the order of 13 February 1991—Report No. 22 of 1994-95—Results of 1993-94 financial statement audits of Commonwealth entities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: There is very little new in this report. It deals with all the audit reports over the 1993-94 financial year. However, I take this opportunity in passing to commend the Auditor-General and his office for their continuing and determined examination of financial results of Australian governmental agencies, federal governmental agencies. I also commend them for their attempts, when denied access by at least one minister, to have appropriate examination of those agencies. This matter is now before the Senate in a bill, which the opposition is seeking to amend, to improve the capacity of the Auditor-General to examine matters which he should properly be examining and where the present law is clearly inadequate in the sense that it does not provide him with opportunities to examine some bodies of the Commonwealth government which are obviously politically sensitive.

PARA.TAB: This report by the Auditor-General reveals that 467 audit reports were issued and only about 39 per cent were qualified. The main reasons for issuing the qualified audit reports were significant inadequacies in systems and controls relating mainly to problems in accounting for and control over assets and the maintenance of adequate financial records, uncertainty resulting from moves to privatise certain entities and breaches of Commonwealth law by departments. For example, the Audit Act requires any instances, with minor exceptions, of non-compliance with the constitution or any law of the Commonwealth to be reported in the audit report. These related mainly to breaches of the Audit Act in respect of the certification of payments and systems supporting the functions.

The report indicates that, while the number of qualified audit reports issued represented an increase from 1992-93—up from 30 to 39, an increase of almost one-third—the analysis the Auditor-General has done indicates that this increase does not in itself project unfavourably on the standard of financial administration by Commonwealth entities. The Auditor-General says that overall the results of the 1993-94 financial statement audits identified a general improvement in the standard of financial management of Commonwealth entities, with audits disclosing that the majority of entities have in place effective control structures which can be relied on to produce accurate and reliable financial statements. As the Auditor-General points out, this was at a time when entities were faced with the need to table their annual reports by October 1994.

For departments and authorities this represented an advance of two months from the previous deadline of 31 December. This chamber is often full of comments about how inadequate various departmental measures are. I commend the departments and agencies that have responded so well to this shortened deadline. The fact that this has been done and that there is better and quicker reporting is largely the result of the pressure this chamber has brought upon the governmental agencies and the government. To that extent it is quite proper that this chamber maintain that pressure, particularly as evident through the Senate estimates committee process.

One of the things that disturbs me is that that process has at present been disrupted by the failure of some ministers' offices to convey to the Senate estimates committees answers to questions which have been on notice since last November and which the agencies themselves assert have been provided to the minister's office, in some instances as long ago as January, but which have still not come to the relevant Senate estimates committees. To an extent some of these are small questions which are not of major moment in determining the estimates. In other cases, they are very important and appear to indicate an extraordinary reluctance on the part of ministers to face up to their responsibilities.

That underlines the important role this chamber, the Senate, fills in making certain that Commonwealth expenditures are properly accounted for. To this extent it is worth noting that the Auditor-General has reported in this report that the audits did, nevertheless, identify deficiencies in the control structure of a number of entities. He has provided a table of details of the more important matters raised with the department and other entities where improvements should be made in their control structure. I do not want to go through all of them; I will just mention a few. For example, it was stated in regard to Film Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: While improvements were evident, the company's systems and controls were found to be deficient in a number of key areas.
In regard to the Commonwealth superannuation administration:

Significant deficiencies existed in systems and procedures for the collection, recording and monitoring of contributions to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and the public sector superannuation scheme.
It was stated in regard to the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service:

Although a number of elements of the control structures were considered to be strong, deficiencies in controls of the IT environment and systems meant the overall control structure could not be relied upon to support reliable accounting systems and effective internal controls.

In regard to the Department of Social Security the Auditor-General mentioned that `continuing shortcomings exist in the recording, reporting and stocktaking of assets, the management of debts and the execution of certain internal controls and checks'.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General also makes a key finding that the Department of Defence did not maintain reliable records of the valuation of administrative assets at military establishments, computer software, intangible assets and accumulated depreciation on combat-related hardware during 1993-94. In addition, combat-related hardware, shown in the financial statements at $3.2 billion, was unable to be confirmed due to deficiencies in the valuation of that portion of the item valued manually and because the automated valuation method that applied to the balance of the item was not supplied for audit assessment.

I do not know the significance of that, apart from the fact that it clearly relates to a very large amount of money. I do not know to what extent you can put a proper value on these assets, particularly combat-related hardware. It does seem that there is a need for this matter to be resolved, and I would hope that the Department of Defence will enthusiastically pursue that matter. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Numerous submissions have been received from various interest groups which raise issues in relation to the legislation which warrant further examination. Some examples of those are:

1.Provisions amending qualification conditions for the sole parent pension which could have the effect of compelling spouses to return to violent domestic situations in order to avoid loss of payment. Civil liberties issues also arise in relation to what may be seen as excessive intrusion into the lives of claimants and their associates when claims are investigated whether in the context of violent spouses or generally.

2.Empowerment of the Secretary of the Department of Social Security to require a person to attend a particular place for a particular purpose as a condition of payment of jobsearch and newstart allowances opens up the prospect for vexatious and unreasonable exercises of discretion. Whilst it may be reasonable to compel a recently arrived migrant to attend certain nominated English classes, it may not be reasonable to require a resident of Melbourne to attend a training course in Sydney. There do not appear to be any inbuilt safeguards which would guard against the exercise of this discretion in a way that may be oppressive for clients.

3.There is generalised concern regarding the expansion of non-reviewable decisions provided for by this legislation. This arises in the context of both decisions by the Minister not to approve applications for exemption from deeming provisions and also decisions by the Employment Secretary not to approve participation by a person in a specified vocational training course or labour market program. The Parliament should exercise reticence in considering any widening of the range of non-reviewable decisions affecting clients under legislation as complex as the Social Security Act 1991.

4.This legislation seeks to empower the Secretary of the Department of Social Security to collect information from not only clients but also "third parties" when assessing entitlement to Seniors' Health Cards. The term "third parties" is not defined and no provision is made for the card applicant to be advised of the information obtained from "third parties". Issues of privacy and confidentiality need to be addressed.

5.Provisions in this legislation also seek to empower the Secretary of the Department of Social Security to delegate the power to determine whether disclosure of information regarding clients should, in the public interest, be disclosed to other Commonwealth Departments or Authorities. Furthermore, such information could be disclosed not only to the Secretary or Head of that other Department or Authority but also to the staff of those outside organisations. These provisions warrant close scrutiny in order to address the issues of privacy and confidentiality which inevitably arise. It is essential that the integrity of client information held by Departments such as that of Social Security be upheld rather than weakened.

6.The potential for maladministration within the Department in relation to debt recovery and the assessment of overpayments arises as a result of provisions which in effect dispense with the need for a Departmental determination as to whether a client is `payable' or not. Under this legislation once a client ceases to be `qualified' according to the statutory criteria, they would also cease to be payable thus giving rise to overpayments. This is at odds with both common sense a series of AAT decisions which affirm the principle that the client remains `payable' until the Department makes a positive determination to the contrary. As a result clients' confidence in the system may well be undermined, quite apart from the laxity in administration that may be fostered within the Department.

Representatives of organisations such as the Welfare Rights Centre; Council on the Ageing; the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission; DEET, the Australian Federal Police and other organisations likely to have reason to seek disclosure of information from the Department of Social Security regarding social security clients.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on National Capital and External Territories, I present the report of the committee on freight and passenger transport to Australia's external territories, entitled Delivering the goods, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I know there are a number of other senators who wish to comment upon the report, so I shall keep my remarks to just some of the matters in which I took a particular interest. I did not go to either Christmas Island or Cocos Island, and other senators are more familiar with those areas.

PARA.TAB: Coming to the last point first, I refer to recommendation 26, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the requirement for Export Clearance Numbers for supplies sent from mainland Australia to the external Territories be abolished, without any change to their Australian duty-free status.

I would recommend to the Commonwealth that that matter be expedited and dealt with. The committee does deal with these external territories and, in particular, of course, that matter which is most important to them because of their isolation—transport. The report is timely because of the fact that the Norfolk Island shipping, as it is presently organised, will shut down at the end of this year, and there seems to be considerable uncertainty in the Western Australian area of shipping to Cocos Island and Christmas Island as well.

PARA.TAB: After looking at a number of options in relation to Norfolk Island, the committee came to the view that the Commonwealth should provide a capital ships grant for the purchase of a vessel to service that island, even though the vessel may not be precisely the size that is required to qualify for such a grant at the present time. It was the view of the committee that some modifications should be made to enable the grant to be applicable to a ship suitable for this service and that that would meet the needs of the islands.

I think all of us recognise that it might be nice to have a large harbour, a marina and all of these things at Norfolk Island but, in view of the size of the population, it would be somewhat difficult to come to this place and suggest that expenditure of that nature be embarked upon by the Commonwealth. Even if that was attractive to the Norfolk Island government and the people of Norfolk Island, one would doubt the ability of a population the size of the island to service the debt involved in that sort of infrastructure itself. We were presented with a proposition which I think most of us felt reasonably met the needs and would enable the transport of goods to continue to Norfolk Island, as it must do.

It is difficult to fully service an island of that size the way one might like to with such a small population. I believe that the integrity of the island, its government and the lifestyle that most people there seem to want should be maintained and that any intervention of the Commonwealth should leave the island pretty much as it is at the present time. I would not see an interventionist role for the Commonwealth government. We have recommended an inquiry on background and funding with some reluctance on my part. I feel that there is a risk that, in doing that, it might be seen as being interventionist in the island's affairs. I would not want that to end up by changing significantly the way the island functions, the way it does business and the way it lives at the present time because it is my belief that most of the people there want it to be the way that it is.

We looked to an extent at the air services to the island and, although there are some difficulties with Norfolk, there are no specific recommendations for action by the Commonwealth that the committee has recommended. It is a bit of a chicken and egg situation—the number of aircraft determine the number of tourists who can visit an island. Then again, if you want to preserve the integrity of the island without having too many people there, you are not going to get the light aircraft in. I think we recognised the difficulties that they are faced with.

We also had the experience of watching the unloading of ships at the present time. It looked pretty hairy to me, but it was not a particularly rough day. I gather on other occasions it might be far more exciting than it was the day that we were there. At present, from fairly old boats servicing the island, the union purchase method of unloading is used of shifting goods into these flat-bottomed whale boats, bringing them into shore and then taking it off again. It basically is fairly dangerous. We also heard of the controversy as to whether container ships would be desirable. We heard evidence for and against the use of containers for the island. I think, on balance, I would take the view that a more secure means of transporting goods there would be more desirable in the end.

I think in view of the time that is available for discussing this matter this afternoon, it is perhaps not a matter that I should continue with at any greater length. I think the committee would feel as I do that we were indebted to those who have serviced the committee: Joanne Towner earlier on and then Meg Crooks; Susan Johnston, as the inquiries secretary; Di Singleton; and Robyn Barter, who were respectively the past and present administrative officers to the committee.

I hope the government will look at our recommendations promptly because, at least as far as Norfolk Island is concerned, I do believe it is necessary to get on with making a decision so that there is no risk of there being any delay in the supply of goods later in the year when the present shipping arrangements will change. It is a difficult matter, but the island must have a service of some kind. I believe what we have recommended enables it to have such a service. There was one dissenting report from Senator Coates that he will speak to. I disagree with the approach he takes to the matters he has raised. I need not say any more about that because he will speak for himself. I commend the report to the Senate and the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be associated with the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. The committee has reported extensively on the reference which it was given in relation to freight difficulties experienced by Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Island and Norfolk Island. The terms of reference are reproduced in the report. To fulfil its duties responsibly, the committee travelled to the three territories to become familiar with them and to hold public hearings. In this respect, the committee visited Christmas Island once, Cocos (Keeling) Island twice and Norfolk Island twice. Public hearings were also conducted in Brisbane, Canberra and Perth.

PARA.TAB: The committee has made 26 recommendations in relation to its terms of reference. Before canvassing any of these recommendations, I intend to mention some matters about the three territories and their inhabitants. Because of their isolation, it would be possible to neglect the needs of these territories. Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Island are directly represented in the federal parliament by senators for the Northern Territory and by the House of Representatives member for the Northern Territory. Even so, because few members of the national parliament visit the territories, it would be easy for the majority of members of the parliament to be unaware of the needs of these two islands.

The same may also be said for Norfolk Island. However, that island has no direct representative link with the federal parliament. It has its own legislature, but its only link to the federal government of the day is via the administrator of Norfolk Island or through the minister for territories or his or her parliamentary secretary. Some of the Norfolk Island residents are enrolled in the electorate of Canberra, but others who can establish a link with another mainland electorate are entitled to be enrolled there. There is no person in the federal parliament who has a direct representative duty to highlight the needs of the Norfolk Islanders and their island government. This lack of direct representation may have to be addressed in the future.

Beyond these factors, however, which could lead to a case of out of sight out of mind, it should be remembered that all three islands—Christmas, Cocos (Keeling) and Norfolk—are Australian territories and are predominantly peopled by Australian citizens. These citizens deserve similar services to those available to their fellow citizens on the Australian mainland. In many respects, this is not the case. If the federal government wishes to fulfil its responsibilities to all Australians, irrespective of where they live, it must be prepared to provide resources for all the territories.

As the title of the report, which has been presented to the Senate today, suggests, it deals principally with problems of freight to and from these island territories. As with many other services, the problems which exist with freight would simply not be endured by mainland communities. None has a river system or a harbour which allows safe loading and unloading of goods transported by sea. Some mainland communities can rely on road transport for the delivery of bulky goods. No such system exists for the three island communities. Apart from the bulk phosphate loading on Christmas Island, goods are loaded and unloaded in conditions which are unsafe for workers and precarious for the goods being transported.

The report entitled Delivering the goods outlines some options for improving the passage of goods and having goods arrive at these territories at a reasonable cost. I do not intend to canvass these recommendations as they are outlined fully in the report, except to make a plea to the government not to place the recommendations in the too hard basket.

Port facilities on Norfolk Island have been a concern raised with the federal government since about the time of Federation. It has never been a responsible attitude to put off making improvements to the island's port facilities. It would be irresponsible to do so now. Norfolk Islanders deserve a regular shipping service and adequate port facilities. The current port at Cascade is a dangerous place to work because of an overhanging and dangerously unstable cliff. Those who are working at Cascade are playing a Norfolk Island game of Russian roulette. It is only a matter of time before someone loses their life because of falling boulders from the cliff. The Norfolk Island stevedores and those who collect and transport goods which have been unloaded deserve far better working conditions.

The report also addresses the issue of air transport to the three territories. Each territory is serviced by Ansett. Christmas Island also receives services from Sampati Air, which operates out of Indonesia, and Norfolk Island has regular Air New Zealand flights from Auckland as well as some less regular flights from some other islands. These air links are vital to the economic well being of each of the islands. The committee has not seen it necessary to make a formal recommendation in relation to air services.

A matter of some concern to the committee and which is featured in the report was a proposed cost increase in the postage rate for mail deliveries from the Australian mainland to Norfolk Island. The island has its own postal service. During the course of the inquiry, I gained the impression that Australia Post resented having to cooperate with the territory postal service, although there was no direct evidence to support my suspicion.

Whatever is the case, the residents of Norfolk Island, who I again stress are predominantly Australian citizens, deserve similar postal services and at similar affordable rates as other like communities on the mainland receive. While Norfolk Island conducts its own postal service, it may set its postal rates as it sees fit. The citizens of Norfolk Island have the opportunity at the elections for their assembly to voice their disapproval if the rates are set too high.

The rates charged by Australia Post for parcel post impact on all Norfolk Island residents because the postal charges are added to the cost of goods purchased on the mainland. While the Norfolk Island government claims that it does not want to be subsidised by Australia Post, it does deserve reasonable rates and it should expect efforts to be made by Australia Post to negotiate more favourable rates for the carriage of mail to Norfolk Island. It is a fact that subsidised rates are not unknown for Australia Post parcel post rates on the Australian mainland and if reasonable rates, subsidised or otherwise, are not set for the carriage of parcels to Norfolk Island more goods could be purchased in New Zealand and sent to Norfolk Island at New Zealand postal rates. Businesses on the Australian mainland would be adversely affected if that occurred.

Of the 26 recommendations in the report, I support all but one—recommendation 15 for which I have only lukewarm support. This recommendation suggests that an investigation be made about the prospects of establishing a coconut oil producing industry on Cocos (Keeling) Island to provide fuel for the island's use. While the proposal has superficial merit, I am yet to be convinced that the energy needed to extract the oil would be less than the energy which would be produced by the end product. Despite my less than enthusiastic support for that recommendation, however, I urge the government to examine all the recommendations carefully and where funds are necessary for their implementation, at least some of those funds be provided in the 1995 federal budget.

Finally, I will express some words of thanks. Firstly, I mention the chairman of the committee, Mr Bob Chynoweth MP, for the sterling way in which he conducted this wide ranging and important inquiry. I also thank the deputy chair, Senator Reid, for her detailed interest and assistance to Mr Chynoweth.

Of course, committee reports like this are not produced without the assistance of a dedicated staff. Those members of the staff should be justly proud of the publication which has resulted. The former secretary of the committee, Joanne Towner, heeded a call to move to a different committee before the inquiry concluded. Meg Crooks took over from Joanne. It is difficult to understand how such a first class report has resulted when Meg did not have the benefit of a visit to the three territories.

Susan Johnston was with the committee for the whole of the inquiry and for a short time was acting secretary. Her detailed knowledge of the issues and evidence was readily apparent when the committee was considering its report. Until Di Singleton left to take up other duties she dealt efficiently with those many administrative tasks which surround inquiries like this. She was ably followed by Robyn Barter who joined the committee in August 1994. I must also mention Margaret Gibson who gave the committee invaluable assistance when public hearings were held on Norfolk Island. This was an interesting and at times demanding inquiry and I have been pleased to have been part of it. Not only do I commend the report to the Senate but I commend it to the government as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories to the Senate and the recommendations to the government. I would like to congratulate the chair of the committee, Mr Bob Chynoweth, on the sterling job that he did. I would also like to congratulate my colleague Senator Margaret Reid, the deputy chairman, particularly in relation to her work on Norfolk Island.

PARA.TAB: I join other senators in very sincerely thanking the former committee secretary, Mrs Joanne Towner, for the sterling work she did. I also thank Susan Johnston who, as Senator Colston said, has been with the committee right through and Di Singleton who did tremendous work for the committee. I also thank Meg Crooks and Robyn Barter who came into the inquiry part way through. The staff have certainly made a major contribution to the writing and tabling of this report and really do deserve our thanks. Some of them looked after us in very difficult circumstances. They even shepherded us into a building when a cyclone was about to hit during our second visit to Cocos Island.

We should also thank all of those people who gave evidence before the committee. The committee travelled to each island twice. We almost became personal friends with a number of people on the various islands. We were aware that many of those people gave up quite a bit to give evidence. Some of them were even courageous in giving evidence in a small community. Their views may not always have been shared by other members of those quite small communities. As I said, on the second occasion that we were on Cocos Island people from Christmas Island who came over to give evidence were, like the committee, caught by the cyclone. It was very inconvenient for them as they could not get off the island. We should acknowledge their role in giving evidence.

There is no doubt that there are real problems with freight on all three islands as they all have very difficult access. This is mainly due to the sheer nature of the coastline on both Norfolk Island and Christmas Island and the difficulties with reefs and moving sands and environmental problems on Cocos Island. The wave action on Christmas Island, which unfortunately I did not see but which we saw photos of, is really quite amazing. One wonders how they get any freight in there at all for many parts of the year. In fact, several weeks—even months—go by at a time when it is impossible to get any sea freight in.

There are obviously very real problems. There are only small populations on each of the islands. In each case, there are only very small economic bases, but the solutions are big money items. There has to be some solutions. The type of freight access to those islands cannot continue as it is. But solutions could be very expensive. It is something that the government will obviously have to think about before any money is spent on those solutions.

I want to indicate at this time that Senator Tambling, who is the coalition's shadow minister for the external territories, did want to make a contribution to this debate on the report but time will not allow him to speak. I do indicate that he will speak later as there are some comments he wishes to make.

Some of the recommendations of the committee deserve some attention by the Senate. I refer to the decision by the committee in the case of each island—Cocos, Christmas and Norfolk—to conduct inquiries by the ABS on the cost of living for those islands vis-a-vis the rest of Australia. A lot of submissions put to us suggested that the cost of living is very high. But some suggestions were made that there were countervailing conditions that perhaps overcame some of that apparent very high cost of living on those islands. It is important that, before decisions are made, we get some idea of just what the cost of living in those communities is in comparison with other parts of Australia, particularly remote mainland Australia.

There have been recommendations to look at new shipping services to Christmas and Cocos islands and perhaps even Norfolk Island. A lot of evidence was given on the part that cabotage played in connection with the cost of getting goods into and out of those islands. The committee with the wisdom of Solomon decided eventually to recommend that, when tenders were called, they be called on two bases—the first where the status quo remained and whereby Christmas and Cocos islands were considered to be part of the coasting trade of Australia and the second where they be granted exemption from cabotage provisions. The tenderers themselves could in the best way possible indicate to us which they preferred. I think that was a good way to do it.

There were recommendations that there be consultations with the Christmas Island workers in relation to the upgrade of the main mooring system. That is quite obvious. There were some important recommendations regarding some environmental problems on Christmas Island due to the storing of drums. There was a recommendation to get rid of those by having bulk storage on Christmas Island in the future. The suggestion of tenders being called for the operation of stevedoring and freight handling on Christmas Island with port facilities being leased by the Commonwealth was a good one and deserves government consideration.

I refer to Cocos Island. The recommendation that the Cocos Island Cooperative Society be reconstituted under Australian law is an important one. There is a real problem there, in that there is a conflict of interest. Most of the board members of the cooperative society are also councillors on Cocos Island's shire council. There are laws in the Western Australian Local Government Act, under which that island now operates, which do have very severe penalties for conflicts of interest. I really think that has to be looked at.

My colleague Senator Colston mentioned recommendation 15 which refers to coconut oil extraction. Whilst I agree that we should not spend a great deal of money on that, I do think it is worth looking at a little further. Obviously, Cocos Island has a helluva lot of coconut trees on it. It is by far the major feature of Cocos Island. If something could be done, it would be of interest.

There is a question about quarantine on both Cocos and Christmas islands. The committee makes recommendations about that. It must be very seriously looked at. The committee rejected almost out of hand the proposal for the inter-island ring road, and I think that is very sensible. It would be foolish to spend any more money on that.

I share Senator Reid's reservations about inquiries into Norfolk Island. It is fair to say that Norfolk Islanders are split on whether they should have closer ties with Australia or whether the existing ties should be removed a bit and made even a little bit more remote. DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1994 [1995]

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill.

—I will not take up much time of the committee on this matter. The coalition wanted a number of matters to be addressed by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee. Those matters have been addressed reasonably well, with the exception of one. The one that has not been dealt with reasonably well—the amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act—is going to be removed from this bill by the government. The removal of this is an example of a couple of things. It is an example of the proper review process taking place resulting in some sort of change. That is not to say that, in the end, these amendments will not come back and we will not agree with them. However, but for the review process and but for sending this off to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, this bill would be proceeding with the changes to the Acts Interpretation Act in it now.

PARA.TAB: You might ask why it should not proceed with those changes in it now. What has happened between the time this bill was last before this chamber and now that makes the government change its mind? To my knowledge, there is nothing—I would be happy to hear if there is—which suggests that the government knows now what it did not know then. In other words, the government was just trying it on and, having got caught out, it has decided to withdraw the amendments it wanted to make.

The parliament has had some difficulty in passing legislation that has, in the end, passed the constitutional hoops that legislation is required to go through when put before the scrutiny of the High Court. This has happened in a number of cases—far too many, I would say—in the last 12 to 18 months. By and large, bills produced by this government have ended up being struck down for invalidity.

One problem that the government struck—in the Lim case in particular, but perhaps in the Herald and Weekly Times case as well—is the main reading of a clause being so wide as to be outside Commonwealth power. The suggestion is that there should be some sort of codification of the tests of severability that the High Court might go through and that the amendments the government was planning on were a proper codification of that. That is a fair way of putting what was put to us at the Senate committee.

It was also put to us—I do not think I am disparaging any committee member improperly by saying that I am not sure we realised it at the time—that a similar clause is now before the High Court in a matter where the judgment will come up by the end of April. We will then know whether the government can get away with doing what it wants to do in amending the Acts Interpretation Act. I am not sure that we all realised it at the time because there was a discussion whereby questions were being asked and answers were being given.

Mr Orr from the department commented on the Herald and Weekly Times case and the industrial relations legislation. He said, `Similar clauses in the Industrial Relations Act are coming up quite soon.' It was easy to see how one could roll together both references to the Industrial Relations Act. That is probably what happened. The penny dropped a little later.

The government has a case coming up in the High Court to be resolved by the end of April and, notwithstanding the fact that similar clauses are in doubt, has thought it might run a bit through the parliament again. I would be very pleased to hear that the rendition I am giving is not correct; it would be the best news I have heard in a long time. It sounds like the government, knowing that some of its legislation is at risk, is prepared to have another crack at it in a much broader sense. Instead of putting a clause of similar effect in one act, it is trying to create a similar effect through the Acts Interpretation Act, which will therefore affect all other legislation.

Why would a government do that? The only reason I can think that the government has withdrawn it is that it is suffering some embarrassment over the Brandy decision. It is just another run of things that the government has been advised is constitutionally okay but which has ended up not being okay. But for good and proper reasons being put together in relation to cabinet advice, I am at a loss to see why any cabinet should rely on the advice as to the constitutionality of a bill that is provided by the Attorney-General's Department.

I do not say that because every time we have to be right. One thing about the constitution is that it is not possible to be right every time. That is why we have the High Court, the number of judges that we have and why lawyers and law students spend hours pouring over one judgment as opposed to another. It is very difficult to produce some pieces of legislation and say with absolute certainty that they will be judged to be constitutional. However, quite frankly, the track record of this government is appalling.

I understand that when A-Gs in a sense goes commercial and other departments are allowed to seek out advice from private solicitors, which is a good thing—there might be some teething problems at the beginning while other departments learn to negotiate price, for example, with private firms in a way that they have not needed to until now—they will be restricted in where they go for their constitutional advice. The monopoly will be with A-Gs. On its record, one wonders why. It is worth making that point.

We support the amendments. We think they should be withdrawn until the position is clarified by the judgment that is coming up. The two points I wanted to make is that the government is simply trying this on. It knew the doubt that exists over this, yet it was going to run another piece of legislation through without telling anybody about the doubt about it.

If we had proceeded without referring this matter to a committee, it would probably have argued with great force the constitutionality of the changes it wants to make. It may end up being right, but the government knows that a minister in here would not have mentioned the pending case in the High Court. It is only by the review process, whereby our bills are referred to committees, that that ever saw the light of day in this chamber. This is another example of it being a good thing. They are basically the two points I want to make. I will not waste anybody else's time by saying any more.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Vanstone is saying about the committee process. I am speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats for Senator Spindler, who had been handling this piece of legislation. The fact that this bill was referred by the Australian Democrats to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has meant that these issues have been raised.

PARA.TAB: I came in here at the time Senator Vanstone was asking why these issues are now being faced up to by the government and why the government has made this decision to withdraw the proposed amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. I suggest to Senator Vanstone that the government read the numbers after that committee hearing and realised that it was not going to get those proposals through the Senate. So, rather than face a Senate-led revolt on yet another piece of legislation and have either the opposition or the Australian Democrats move them for it, it decided to go ahead with its amendments instead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Pages 20 to 21, Schedule 2, item 1, omit the item.

I will be brief. The proposed amendments will delete the amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act included in the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 [1995] as originally moved. The amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act was to insert a new reading-down provision—proposed section 15AAA—into the Acts Interpretation Act.

PARA.TAB: Some concerns about this amendment were raised at the Senate committee hearing on 10 February. Subsequently, on 14 February, argument was heard in the High Court in

SPEECH.PARA: re Munro ex parte Wagner on the constitutional validity of a similar provision to the one proposed as section 15AAA—namely, section 17A of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Judgment on the issues argued at the hearing is expected soon. In light of this, the government considers that the most prudent course of action is to await the views of the High Court on the validity of section 17A of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 before deciding whether to proceed to enact a similar provision of the general application of the Commonwealth statutes.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2, page 34, at end of Schedule, add the following amendment:

`(7)Nothing in Division 1 or 2, as applying by reference to section 6, affects anything done by a person, after the disallowance of regulation 16, in compliance with paragraph 67(b) of the Austudy Regulations as that paragraph was in force on 31 December 1994.
`(8)In subsection (7), "regulation 16" means regulation 16 of the Austudy Regulations (Amendment) contained in Statutory Rules 1994 No. 409 and disallowed by the Senate on 9 February 1995.'."

The amendment that the Greens are moving to the Law and Justice Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 is the one circulated in my name. This is an omnibus bill to enable married students under the age of 22 to retain Austudy. Austudy regulation SR 1994 No. 409 repealed paragraph 67(b) of the main Austudy regulations. The intention was to terminate the independent living allowance for married students. A grandfather regulation protected married students already in receipt of an allowance.

PARA.TAB: On 9 February 1995, the Senate disallowed the amendment. Paragraph 67(b) will therefore revive from that date, as if it had never been repealed, subsection 48(7) of the Acts Interpretations Act 1901. However, it is claimed by the government that it cannot pay the allowance because to do so would be unlawful under section 6 of part 2 of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 relating to discrimination on the ground of marital status. The proposed amendment removes the risk of such illegality by providing that nothing in those provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act affects actions by a person to implement paragraph 67(b) of the Austudy regulations.

The government has clearly been unjustified and unjust in its cynical moves to take Austudy off young married people. The government has tried hard to prevent the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the opposition from stopping its unfair changes from going ahead through a tangled regulatory framework for Austudy and the coincidental expiry of the exemption of married students from the Sex Discrimination Act. The Greens believe that an amendment to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) will lead us out of this quagmire and deliver justice to young married students at the same time. Our simple amendment extends the exemption of Austudy regulation 67(b) from the Sex Discrimination Act.

I recapitulate the main points of this issue. The government has decided to take Austudy off young married independent students under the age of 22 by saying that an exemption to the Sex Discrimination Act has expired so that it is illegal to act to grant Austudy to married students and not students in de facto relationships. However, the government is not prepared to give Austudy to students in de facto relationships under the age of 22, so it is taking the amoral stance of taking it off all young married students.

Including the government's weak efforts, no-one can justify taking independence allowance off a married student and, by doing so, claim that they are not independent. Marriage in any society, including our own, is one of the first indications of independence. People should not be refused an allowance because they are independent and happen to be married. This is discrimination in itself.

If the government believes people are getting married, which is a pretty big step, to receive Austudy, I have not seen it giving us any evidence of that. It should find another way of abolishing fraud than abolishing a whole category of Austudy and disadvantaging all those young students with genuine marriages.

If students are getting married to get an allowance this surely would tell the government of their desperation to support themselves while they gain their higher qualifications. This is a sign that they are willing to deal with the poverty associated with studying which Austudy maintains. They would be financially better off on the dole. I will read examples of some of the difficulties faced by students who have contacted the Greens, pleading for us to do something to stop the government from taking Austudy off them. Many of the students who have contacted me questioned whether they can return to study this year without any kind of financial support. This student states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am 21 and studying medicine and my husband is 23 and doing his masters of Engineering so he is already ineligible for Austudy. The new changes mean my only option is to quit Medicine for the year and go on the dole while looking for work.

My only option is to get part time work while studying that pays more than $70 per week. I don't need to point out to you how far below the poverty line this puts me—this is a denial of the means to fulfil basic human needs such as food and shelter.

It is offensive to me that the Government obviously doesn't consider my marriage to be legal and honourable. I can think of no sane person who would undertake the enormous commitment of marriage for the $120 per week that Austudy used to supply.

In a few years time my income will be up to $100,000 per annum. However, this is conditional on support to continue my studies this year without malnutrition. It is extremely short-sighted and totally unjust that we are denied the right to continue our higher education. If Australia wants to become the clever country we had better start supporting our students and not starving them.
This is one from the parents' viewpoint. One parent states:

My daughter, a university student, will turn 20 this year and will marry in July yet the Austudy changes mean she will be treated as if living off my wife's income until she reaches the age of 22. It seems incongruous to me that my daughter and her fiance are being penalised because they have decided to uphold their strong Christian values, with both families' blessings, and they would be entitled to many more Government benefits, if they hadn't.

These letters say it all. The government could have been fairer and prevented students from experiencing a lot of pain if they had simply extended the exemption for married students from the Sex Discrimination Act. This is not a lot of money. I understand that it affects only some 2,000 students, so the usual economic rationalist arguments have no place here. Again, we see a situation where the government has not done its job properly by neglecting students in this case and so the Greens, the opposition and the Democrats have to tidy up the mess that remains.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government objects to this amendment on a couple of grounds. Firstly, it had no notice of this amendment. Secondly, on principle we object to the use of an omnibus bill to amend acts not already amended in the bill. The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 is not an act referred to in the bill before the committee. Because of this, we are not in a position to analyse the effect of the amendment. We do not know that everything Senator Margetts is seeking to do is being done correctly or accurately matched against the Sex Discrimination Act because we simply have not had the opportunity to check on it.
—Well, you had an exemption. Why don't you just carry on with the exemption?
—Don't get worked up. I will just get some advice on that, but that is where we are at the present time. I will do as has been suggested. I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I might just say something that could help the government's consideration overnight. I thought it might be helpful to say that, in the short time the opposition has had to consider the matter, it does seem to us to be a way to restore fairness and justice. We believe that married students should be treated as independent. We, in our recall of the Sex Discrimination Act debate, actually believed it was primarily aimed at avoiding married people's being discriminated against for that fact. It seems to be somewhat twisted logic for the government now to be arguing the opposite.

PARA.TAB: There is a background to this that deals with the grandfathering provision included in the government's regulation. Although the government was to act so that in the future this benefit would be removed from married students under the age of 22, it was intending to grandfather those who were currently receiving benefits. Since then, we certainly—perhaps the minor parties as well—have been having some dealings with the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) to facilitate a grandfathering clause being included. But that solves only half the problem because we say that not only should those who are currently receiving benefits have their position preserved but that it should also apply to those who have not been receiving that benefit but who marry and should therefore clearly, in the eyes of all sensible people, be treated as independent of their parents in terms of assets tests and income tests, notwithstanding that they might be less than 22 years of age.

Therefore, we have urged the government to look at a method of restoring the original position. We have said that we see there are two ways open in which that could be done. The first is to seek an additional exemption under the Sex Discrimination Act and the other is to seek an amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act. The Greens have, without any communication with us, astutely picked up that option as being open under this legal omnibus bill and therefore are taking this opportunity to seek to amend the Sex Discrimination Act.

Although that might be somewhat unusual in that, as the minister's representative said, the Sex Discrimination Act was not being amended by the government's bill, the advice that we have received to date is that that does not provide a procedural barrier and that it is within the competence of the chamber to introduce an amendment to a new bill under the umbrella of an omnibus bill that the government has brought to this place.

The minister's representative will no doubt go away and take good advice overnight. As we understand it at the moment, it is within the province of this chamber to act in this way. If it is, then we think it is an amendment that would achieve the objectives that we have been seeking to achieve and that we sought to achieve by our original notice of disallowance. Therefore, we would be inclined to support the amendments before the chamber. I thought if I put that on the record at this stage it might help the government overnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will speak very briefly to the government's motion. The full title of this particular bill that we are looking at is `an Act to amend various acts relating to law and justice, and for related purposes'. It deals with AAT matters, the Acts Interpretation Act, Federal Court arbitration, et cetera. It contains in proposed section 15AAA of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 the provision virtually to destroy the High Court's jurisdiction to rule on the constitutionality of legislation. The Sex Discrimination Act falls within the Attorney-General's portfolio. Therefore, I would support the words of Senator Hill in this case, that it definitely falls within the ambit of this omnibus bill. Therefore, there is no real reason why amendments cannot be dealt with in this particular bill.

—by leave—Just to assist in the process, which Senator Hill described as a process of thinking overnight, as to what advice the government might seek, I think it may be appropriate to remind the government that Senator Margetts's amendment would be seen to be appropriate because the government has failed to come up with an adequate definition of `independence' with regard to receipt of Austudy. It is the independence rate which the government had previously attempted to define as being available under certain situations.

PARA.TAB: One of those situations had been an age qualification. The qualification had been the age of 25 and it has been progressively reduced each year to the stage where it is now over 22. What is very important here is that the government should perhaps consider coming up with a more adequate definition of `independence' than age. After all, age is really not adequate in any sense of the word in describing students' actual situations and competencies.

We have a number of other moments of life, rites of passage they may or may not be, after which people become, in effect, adults; and probably the most significant of those remaining is the acquisition of the right to vote, which is an age qualification, as is the capacity to enter into a contract or to acquire debt or, for that matter, to consent to sexual intercourse. There are many age based measures upon which legal decisions of our society are made, but there are also traditions, mores and values that are held.

The concept of people who are married being still dependent on their parents is foreign in our society and is defied by commonsense and practice. It is because of that that such indignation is being expressed to the regulation which has been proposed by the government. I am trying to remind the government's advisers that it is that indignation that has driven a lot of what is seen here, not so much people who are concerned about the dollars and cents of the matter, although that is significant, but rather the denial of the very fact of what marriage represents—it is the step to establish an independent family unit; it is the leaving of the family nest; it is so much of what we have come to understand as being the basis of our society.

To deny all those actualities or that reality is to come up with bureaucratic nonsense. So it is in seeking to remove that that I think Senator Margetts rightly brings this amendment before us, and that is why we would support it—it recognises real life much more adequately than the other proposals we have had. If the government were able to display initiative and imagination and come up with a proper definition of `independence', we would all be better off and we would be able to make sense of Austudy regulations and the Sex Discrimination Act. So I would hope that in the time the government has now it can see the sense of properly defining what an independent person is so that such a person can properly receive the independent rate of Austudy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
