DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNICATIONS AND THE ARTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994 [1995]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Communications and the Arts Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 [1995] is an omnibus amendment bill which makes amendments to six acts in the Communications and the Arts portfolio. The most contentious of these are amendments removing ministerial approval requirements for contracts above $20 million taken out by the ABC and SBS. I would like to foreshadow at this point that the coalition will be moving an amendment to this aspect of the bill in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: The bill also implements a new apparatus licensing system, following a public inquiry by the Spectrum Management Agency. The bill introduces transferable apparatus licences for particular pieces of equipment which are currently not directly transferable. The bill also seeks to make two non-contentious changes to the operation of the Australian Film and Television School. Also included in the bill are a number of non-contentious amendments to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. The local content provisions which currently apply only to satellite licences are extended to all subscription services. The bill clarifies the circumstances in which the ABA can deem that a drama program made wholly or substantially in Australia is non-Australian.

The coalition supports these amendments that are outlined in the bill. However, we have a number of concerns about the proposed amendment which would remove the requirement of the ABC and SBS to obtain ministerial approval before entering into contracts or lease back arrangements worth more than $20 million. The bill is expected to have no financial impact coming from these changes.

In the committee stage, the coalition will move an amendment to the bill requiring that the ABC and SBS notify the Minister for Communications and the Arts at least 14 days in advance of an intention to enter into such contracts. The government claims that the responsibility for these decisions should rest with the respective boards of the ABC and SBS. It has also claimed that these national broadcasters—given that they are statutory independent bodies—should be able to make decisions on their financial management without any government scrutiny. It is claimed that the minister will not have access to the detailed commercial information needed to make an informed decision about the appropriateness of these contracts or arrangements.

The ABC has said that, under the current system, it seeks ministerial approval on 30 to 40 occasions each year. The ABC argues that this provision is out of date, as the prudential supervision is now set at the macro level by way of corporate plans. It claims that the minister is unlikely to veto a board decision, as he could be seen to be interfering with the ABC board. SBS has sought ministerial approval on contracts worth more than $20 million only once in the past year.

In considering our position on this aspect of the bill, the coalition has weighed the arguments of the national broadcaster with other issues of national interest. Both ABC and SBS finances come from parliamentary appropriations, and ministerial scrutiny is, therefore, highly desirable. Friends of the ABC are opposed to the removal of ministerial approval provisions, saying that the ABC belongs to the taxpayer and not to the ABC board.

The public concern about the management and operation of the ABC requires very careful consideration by this parliament. There must be a certain level of accountability and ministerial scrutiny. We have seen evidence of the need for this in past months in the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, which is inquiring into the administration of the ABC under the chairmanship of David Hill. The public debate has centred on ABC decisions that have related to non-core activities. We have looked at a range of ABC enterprises—the BNA wire service, Australian Television International and movements into pay television—and we have heard evidence that the tendency to become involved in commercial ventures has significant risks attached to it.

As taxpayers' money is involved with the ABC, there is obviously a need for scrutiny of its charter and non-charter activities. This involves not only the normal ways that it spends its recurrent funding but also the ways that it spends its capital funding, because we found from the evidence on the record before the committee that it is actually constructing a building related to pay TV operations in the middle of facilities for the core activity operations. This raises a number of issues and is a good reason why I believe there is a need for the minister to have some sort of prudential supervision over, or knowledge of—and that is all that we are requiring in the amendments that we have foreshadowed—what the ABC is doing.

The ABC and SBS should really let the minister know when they are moving in these directions. We do not think it is unreasonable to give the minister that sort of advice 14 days in advance. For this reason, my colleague Senator Alston has circulated amendments to subsection 71 of the ABC Act 1983 and subsection 67(1) of the SBS Act 1991.

The coalition amendments require that both the ABC and SBS notify the minister of the need to enter contracts worth more than $20 million at least 14 days in advance and retain a proper level of accountability. This will ensure the balance that is necessary in the proper running of the ABC and SBS, which are both using public money. In principle, the opposition does not believe that we can move from a position of ministerial scrutiny—when the minister is reviewing quite a number of contracts every year—to a position when he does not review anything. The government has mentioned previously the need for this change, because it claims the minister cannot be expected to exercise that level of scrutiny or have the knowledge that is needed in these sorts of commercial arrangements. We believe that the amendment will force the minister to have proper overview.

It is no accident that the present level of concern about the ABC and its management is really happening under the stewardship of Minister Lee. David Hill has now left the ABC. His last effort was the hosting of Lateline last week. Mr Hill did not give a vote of confidence in this minister. David Hill gave the minister a major parting shot, saying that the growing perception and reality is that ABC board appointments are as a result of political affiliation. This minister and the ABC are responsible for the board's loss of independence by undertaking this process. If there is a perception that the board is not completely independent, then there is a greater need to ensure that there is some scrutiny by this parliament—indeed some scrutiny by the minister.

This minister needs to have scrutiny in a number of areas not only those relating to the ABC and its management and operations. We also have before us examples, such as the West Indies cricket fiasco and the media rules policy—and that at the moment is an absolute mess, with one eleventh hour remission on the West Indies test series tonight and with us not knowing what will happen in the future. Therefore, we need a minister who is a bit more hands-on with what is happening in the communications area, whether it be cross-media rules or the management and operations of the ABC and SBS.

On these amendments to the ABC and SBS now before the Senate, the coalition seeks to have the minister keep his responsibilities over these two bodies where large sums of money, such as $20 million and over, are being expended. We are balancing ministerial responsibility and accountability with the level of independence of the ABC and SBS.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a few comments in response to Senator Tierney's contribution to this debate. I find it a bit surprising that Senator Tierney seems to be in sympathy with Mr David Hill—paraphrasing Senator Tierney's comments—and his suggestion that the ABC is no longer independent, the board is no longer independent or, at least, there is a perception that it is no longer independent. By way of dealing with this, Senator Tierney proposes that the parliament should have the right to investigate, within 14 days or less, things that the ABC board might be planning to do. What kind of support for independence is that? It certainly seems to me that Senator Tierney's proposed amendments run completely counter to the arguments that he was putting, as I understood them.
—It is a spurious argument.

—He said that it was a spurious argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Financial Management and Accountability Bill, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, the Auditor-General Bill and the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill are a package of bills which replace and repeal the Audit Act 1901. These bills represent the long overdue overhaul and improvement of the legal framework which encompasses the accountability of public finances at the Commonwealth level. Indeed, no legislation could be more important to the parliament than this package of legislation and I believe that there will be no more important package of legislation presented, certainly not in the life of this parliament.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I express my concern and disappointment that this legislation is in fact being debated today. As I understand it, the coalition sought to have its consideration deferred until tomorrow for the very simple and proper reason that there has been a Senate committee looking at it. That committee reported only today—indeed, in the last hour. So we are going into the second reading debate without senators, including some of those speaking in the second reading debate, having had the opportunity to consider the report of that committee. I put in a protest to the government on this.

If we are serious and fair dinkum about having proper parliamentary consideration of legislation—particularly vital legislation of this nature, which goes to the whole core of accountability of government, the role of the parliament and the executive and the like, and given that this package of legislation has been six years in the making—it would have been much more in accord with the proper processes of parliamentary procedure for it at least to have been deferred until tomorrow before it came up for debate.

These bills are the outcome of the 1989 report No. 296 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament—Reform of the Australian Audit Office. That very carefully considered and very highly reputable report recommended, amongst other things, that the Audit Act be repealed and replaced with more modern and flexible financial management.

This legislation was supposed to be introduced in the 1992 autumn sittings, that is, three years ago. It was deferred then as a low priority item by the government, despite its obvious importance. It was then proposed for the 1993 autumn sittings. Again it was postponed, and the bills first appeared in late June last year. It is planned that the new arrangements will take effect on 1 July this year. If they do—if the government does meet that starting point deadline, as hopefully it now will—it will be six long years after initially being recommended that the package is finally put into place. To quote the then Auditor-General from the 1991-92 annual report of the Australian National Audit Office:

SPEECH.PARA: In my report some three years ago—
and he is saying this in 1991-92—

I reported with some enthusiasm government support for the JCPA's recommendation that a new act be developed setting a new direction for my office. That enthusiasm has waned somewhat. Some four years after the JCPA recommended its development, the reality of a new act would still seem to be in the future. I hope that the parliament will be put in a position soon where it will be able to put the Auditor-General's act in place by July 1993. However, the Government has recently reduced the priority given to the passage of the legislation, which may leave the Office without the support it needs in the contemporary environment.
So said the Auditor-General in the 1991 annual report. He was then at pains to comment on the issue again in his 1992 annual report:

During the year, however, it became more obvious to me that the changes in the Australian National Audit Office had to be more fundamental and far reaching. It became clear to me that I could no longer afford to wait for the government to act to implement the recommendations made by the JCPA in its report 296 of March 1989.
The 1993-94 annual report contained the following references to the matter in what became Mr John Taylor's last report on the issue before his retirement. In that 1993-94 annual report he said:

1993-94 saw the introduction of a package of legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. Five years after it was first recommended by the JCPA, three Bills, including the Auditor-General Bill, were introduced in the House of Representatives by the Government. In a welcome initiative the Government at the same time referred those bills to the JCPA for review.

The next few months represent a crucial period for the Australian National Audit Office with the expected passage of the legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. I am greatly encouraged, in particular, by the JCPA's support for providing the Auditor-General with the authority to set its own terms and conditions of the staff of the Audit Office and for the establishment of an Audit Committee of the Parliament. With these important building blocks, the prospect of a long-term improvement in the Australian National Audit Office's funding position, and the continuing commitment and professionalism of all the staff of the ANAO, I am cautiously optimistic that the Audit Office will continue to provide the Parliament, the Executive and the community with a valued service well into the future.
It is now up to the Parliament to decide what it, rather than the Government or its agencies, wants from the Auditor-General and the Australian National Audit Office.

That is exactly what the coalition parties will be pushing for in the Senate in the debate both at the second reading stage and, more particularly, the committee stage of these bills. We will be moving a number of amendments. They have been formally circulated in my name on behalf of the coalition. They are all designed to enhance the role and responsibilities of the Auditor-General and, through him, the accountability of government to the people and to the parliament.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Gibson, who is a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and who will be dealing with these bills for the coalition not only in the second reading stage but also in the committee stage, will outline in more detail the proposals and the considerations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which deliberations have been important in framing the recommendations and amendments that we will be moving.

In its 1989 report, the key report, No. 296, entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the people and the parliament, the Public Accounts Committee set out clearly why it considered new audit legislation was necessary. It gave the following reasons: that it was necessary to establish the Audit Committee of Parliament; to identify the Auditor-General more clearly as an officer of the parliament—and that is a key point; to establish the procedures for appointing future auditors-general and to change procedures for their removal; to change the term of appointment of future auditors-general; to define the Auditor-General's authority to settle the terms and conditions of employment of the Australian Audit Office staff; to extend the Auditor-General's power to delegate his authority to settle the terms and conditions of employment of Australian Audit Office staff; to extend the Auditor-General's powers to delegate his authority; to affirm that the Auditor-General is the external auditor of all Commonwealth bodies and organisations in which the Commonwealth has a controlling interest; to affirm the Auditor-General's authority to initiate efficiency audits of all Commonwealth instrumentalities; to place beyond doubt the Auditor-General's authority to contract audits to whom he or she considers appropriate; to simplify statements of the Auditor-General's authority in relation to regularity and performance audits; to rename the Australian Audit Office; to reaffirm the role of the independent auditor of the Australian Audit Office in the light of these legislative changes; and, most importantly, to provide the Australian Audit Office with a clearer definition of its role in government.

The coalition wholeheartedly endorses the approach and recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee and so, as I have already noted, did the Auditor-General. We have been very supportive of the thrust of this package of bills, which is the government's very belated response to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report of 1989. A `disgrace' is the only word that can accurately describe the delay that has occurred in the development of these bills and their presentation to the parliament. We are very fortunate indeed that we have not had some serious problems arise over financial accountability and the auditor's role in the ensuing years while that hiatus has occurred.

We do regret very much, however, whilst being supportive of the thrust of this package of bills, that the government has not been prepared to embrace more fully the Public Accounts Committee's proposals. The amendments that I have circulated on behalf of the coalition are aimed at addressing those deficiencies. We believe that there are four serious shortcomings in the legislation as proposed by the government. They deal with the following four issues: firstly, the appointment of the Auditor-General; secondly, the mandate of the Audit Office; thirdly, the question of an Audit Committee of Parliament and, fourthly, the terms and conditions of employment at the Audit Office.

In each of these cases the government has failed to respond adequately to the original Public Accounts Committee report and also to the follow-up report on this legislative package, that report being No. 331 of the Public Accounts Committee of September 1994. That report reiterated and identified these very same shortcomings as they exist in the current Audit Act arrangements and as will be the case in the government's preferred bills.

The appointment of the Auditor-General surely should be above party politics. The occupant of this highly respected and critically important position should have the support of both the government and the opposition and the endorsement of the parliament's audit committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not mind having a say either.

—I take your point, Senator Kernot. This is required in order to enhance the Auditor-General's perception of independence and of his relationship with the parliament. The Auditor-General's mandate should be clear. It should include all taxpayer instrumentalities and agencies. That should be included in the statute and not be subject to ministerial fiat or regulation. The coalition's amendments adequately protect commercial government business enterprises, as vetted by the audit committee, while at the same time ensuring an easier avenue for proper accountability of taxpayer funds.

PARA.TAB: The audit committee concept is a long overdue measure to enhance the relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament. The coalition's amendments propose that this role be carried out by the new Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit. This new committee would oversee the Auditor-General, guide the Auditor-General and review the work of the Auditor-General. It would play a fundamentally important role in the parliament in guaranteeing the utmost accountability of taxpayer funds, and that surely is the ultimate responsibility of any parliament.

The final point of contention is over the terms and conditions of staff at the audit office. This is a fundamental bone of contention. It is, in our view, essential that the Auditor-General not be thwarted by the government of the day through the imposition of rigid and inappropriate Public Service conditions. He needs flexibility in dealing with his staff. His office, and especially his staff, need to be fully independent of any control by government. My colleagues, and in particular Senator Gibson, will be further elaborating on these issues in the second reading debate and in the committee stage.

The final subject I wish to address, and which is essential to the coverage of the Auditor-General, is the inclusion of the National Media Liaison Service, more commonly known as aNiMaLS, in his audit mandate. aNiMaLS is, of course, nothing other than the government's propaganda wing, or at least that is what it has become. It should never have been that, but that is what it has become during the life of this government.

Last year the audit office commenced a routine efficiency audit of government information and advertising. In October 1994, the audit office sought an interview with aNiMaLS `for the purpose of continuing with the audit'. aNiMaLS refused and referred the matter to the Minister for Administrative Services. On 5 December last year, after a request from the acting Auditor-General for assistance, the minister replied that `the review you propose is ultra vires the Audit Act'.

SPEECH.PARA: That opinion was supported then by the Attorney-General's Department.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General in Audit Report No. 17, 1994-95 entitled National Media Liaison Service—a loophole in accountability? summarised the position as follows. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: NMLS is therefore not subject to the normal accountability mechanisms in place over Government programs. As a consequence, although NMLS is fully funded by the taxpayer and its stated roles and functions are predominantly administrative in nature, its operations are not subject to the scrutiny normally associated with the expenditure of public monies.

In effect, $1.5 million of taxpayer funds are absolved of any accountability; those funds being used, as I say, for the blatant purpose of political propaganda by this government. Of course, there can be no excuse for its exclusion from normal accountability procedures and avenues. The Auditor-General concluded his report No. 17 with this warning:

All those who play a role in administrative decision making exercise public power and that action, especially where public money is involved, should be open to public scrutiny. The Auditor-General Bill before Parliament does not provide explicitly that the performance audit mandate of the Auditor-General extends to activities such as those of NMLS. I understand, however, that it is intended that this will be addressed by regulation only and therefore not be a central tenet in the provisions of the legislation. The accountability arrangements for all activities that involve the use of taxpayers' funds should be enshrined as a central tenet of the provisions of any new Auditor-General Act.

The coalition agrees totally with that view, and we will be pursuing that very strongly in the further consideration of this bill. As I say, the coalition supports the bill. We regret that it has not gone far enough to meet the Public Accounts Committee's recommendations. We hope that, as a result of this debate, those concerns will be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating four bills which, collectively, are probably the most important legislative package on government accountability that this parliament will consider. Before us are the three bills proposed to replace the Audit Act 1901, as well as a bill of miscellaneous amendments. It was appropriate that the Audit Act, which established the office of the Auditor-General and the basic rules governing government money, was the first act of the new federal parliament in 1901. But, having said that, it is extraordinary that it has taken 94 years for the act to be finally revised and updated.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats wish to place on the record our strong support for the need for the package of bills. While the bills are not perfect, they go some significant way, in our view, to implementing a key plank of the accountability package which the Democrats negotiated with the government following the resignation of Mrs Ros Kelly in March last year. These bills will strengthen the statutory independence of the Auditor-General and, if amended as we have sought, they will establish an appropriate link between the Auditor-General and the parliament through an audit committee of the parliament.

This package of bills, as we have said, has been a long time coming. It was first recommended 18 years ago by the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. The recommendations of that royal commission on financial management were then largely ignored by successive governments, Labor and coalition.

Five years ago, the Public Accounts Committee conducted a detailed inquiry of the office of the Auditor-General and found that the office was suffering from defective legislation, inadequate funding and unnecessary interference from the executive arm of government. The Public Accounts Committee's call for urgent action was ignored for many years, despite repeated calls from the Auditor-General for a stronger statement of his role as a servant of the parliament and for adequate funding arrangements for him to carry on his duties.

Instead, I think it is fair to say, the government chose to make it progressively harder for the audit office to function. Between 1992 and 1994, the parlous finances of the office forced a reduction in staff from 650 to 350 employees. I do not think that is just the normal downsizing. I think it has to do with lack of money. This has meant that many reporting functions which could have been done have not been done.

On top of that, the audit office faced a cumulative loss of a further $23 million over 15 years as a result of a badly negotiated lease with its head tenant, the ALP. While a commission of inquiry cleared the government and the ALP of any wrongdoing with the lease, it has pointed out that, unless the financial obligations under the lease are met by government, the audit office's capacity to undertake its statutory obligations will be affected.

In March 1994, following the resignation of Mrs Kelly, the Democrats extracted from the government an agreement to an accountability package which guaranteed a stronger role for the Auditor-General. Since last March, these bills have been extensively redrafted and now promise to establish a very strong financial accountability regime for the government, departments and Commonwealth agencies and authorities.

Establishing a strong legislative mandate for a well resourced Auditor-General is a key priority for the Democrats. This can only benefit good government. Not just will it improve accountability, but it will also lead to more efficient government. It is worth pointing out that performance audits by the Auditor-General have, even in just the last few years, identified potential savings to the government of hundreds of millions of dollars.

Certainly these bills we are debating look a whole lot better than the draft bill I saw a year ago. I think we should commend the government and Minister Beazley on their preparedness, since the March accountability statement, to entertain further strengthening of the financial accountability of government. Having said that, I still believe that we need to go a little further to develop the proper role of parliament in keeping the executive arm of government fully accountable. In the committee stage, the Democrats and the opposition will be moving various amendments which we believe will improve these bills. I hope that the government will match its rhetoric with an even stronger legislative commitment to keep itself financially honest.

We have four bills before us. I will briefly deal with each of them and highlight what, in our view, still needs to be done. Politically, the most important bill is the Auditor-General Bill. This will establish the office of the Auditor-General, its mandate, its powers and its responsibilities. The government has agreed to expand the authority of the Auditor-General to give it the automatic right to audit all government bodies for financial statement audits and all bodies, except GBEs, on performance audits. This is a great improvement on the existing position, but still does not go far enough.

The Democrats believe that the public has a right to know that government owned enterprises can be subject to performance audits. GBEs often like to think that they can operate like private sector companies. Private sector companies are responsible to their shareholders for their performance. Such mechanisms do not exist for GBEs, which are wholly government owned. For these reasons we will be supporting a further extension of the Auditor-General's mandate on efficiency audits. In our view, the Auditor-General should also have the right to audit all organisations run with government money. The recent case of the National Media Liaison Service, where a $1.5 million government agency was excluded from performance audits, should never recur.

We will be moving amendments to ensure that the Auditor-General's right to audit other government bodies should not be constrained and this right to report on those activities should not be fettered unless the Auditor-General believes that it would not be in the public interest to report on matters. Most importantly, the bill must make clear that the Auditor-General's primary role is to assist parliament in making sure the executive arm of government is accountable to it. We seek to achieve this in several ways.

Firstly, we propose to give the parliament a say in the development of the budget and audit priorities of the audit office through the establishment in law of an audit committee of parliament. This would follow the practice of both the British and Canadian parliaments, which have established such committees. In following the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee, the Democrats propose that the role of the audit committee be performed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts with an extended list of duties and its membership extended to include minority party representation. Senator Short said that he hoped that the appointment of the Auditor-General would be something agreed to by the government and the opposition. I think he would recognise that considering we had a say in the original accountable package we would have an interest in this appointment as well.

Secondly, we propose that the parliament should have a say in the appointment of the Auditor-General. We have proposed the adoption of the model used in the New South Wales parliament of giving the extended Public Accounts Committee the right to investigate and, if necessary, veto the nomination of an Auditor-General.

The second key piece of legislation is the Financial Management and Accountability Bill. In practical terms this is probably the most far reaching of the three bills. It dramatically changes the way in which Commonwealth government funds are to be held by agencies and it establishes a range of new responsibilities. The Democrats support the broad thrust of the legislation, as expressed in clause 45, that will require chief executives to manage the affairs of their agencies in a way that promotes the efficient, effective and ethical use of public moneys.

In the course of hearings on this bill, the Privacy Commissioner and the ombudsman have raised some concerns about elements of the bill. The Privacy Commissioner is concerned that clause 36 of the bill allows the finance machine to reward informants. In our view, this enactment runs contrary to the advice of the Senate whistleblowers committee and the Elliott House Committee on Fraud. We intend to move to delete this provision.

The ombudsman remains concerned that the proposed finance regulations underpinning the bill will establish an overly complex system for the determination of compensation to the victims of government maladministration. We have looked at this and we share some of those concerns. We seek a commitment from the government that the proposed regulatory scheme will be the subject of close consultation with the Democrats and a public inquiry before being enacted.

The third major bill is the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. This bill establishes an accountability regime for government business enterprises, statutory authorities, and government owned companies. We will support this bill as it seeks to establish proper lines of accountability to the government for the financial performance of these enterprises, authorities and companies. However, as I indicated earlier, we will be seeking to improve the further line of accountability from government business enterprises to the parliament by expanding the mandate of the Auditor-General over performance audits.

We will also be seeking to amend the CAC bill to correct a possible unintended consequence. Clause 28 of the bill allows the relevant minister to issue instructions to Commonwealth authorities. In the case of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, this section effectively repeals section 8 of the ABC Act, which guarantees the independence of the ABC in all matters. The Democrats believe that the ABC Act, which allows the government to propose policy to the board and for the board to consider the government's proposal, provides a reasonable compromise between the need for the ABC to be accountable and also independent. We will be moving to exclude the ABC from the operation of clause 28.

The fourth bill deals with various miscellaneous and transitional amendments and we will be moving only one amendment to set a maximum time within which regulations to govern the auditing of security and intelligence agencies will be enacted. In summary, the package of bills before us tonight will help us keep the government honest. We support that principle. However, it must be taken further. Financial accountability is not just about agencies being accountable to the government and the executive; it is about the executive being accountable to the parliament and through the parliament to the public at large.

We always have to keep pulling back to maintain that position. It is hard and we all understand why governments try to get away with as much as they can until we tell them they cannot. We are telling them on this one that they cannot get away with it and we need them to go further. While we recognise the package of bills represents a significant move towards the goal of the executive ultimately being accountable through parliament to the public at large, the Democrats' amendments will go even further and are necessary to achieve that particular goal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Short, who spoke on behalf of the coalition in relation to this package of bills. I will very briefly go back over the history of the legislation. Report No. 296 of the Public Accounts Committee entitled Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, which was tabled in April 1989, was a key document in relation to this legislation. As Senator Short said, it took the government until autumn of last year before it agreed to look at that report and bring forward a draft amendment to the Audit Act 1901.

PARA.TAB: On 29 June last year the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) introduced into the other place the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 and the Auditor-General Bill 1994 and immediately referred them to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which was to report on them. The next day the Senate asked the public accounts committee to report on the government notice of motion to establish an audit committee of the parliament, following a draft resolution that was brought forward here in the Senate.

In September of last year report No. 331 of the public accounts committee, which was tabled on 22 September, basically reviewed the legislation before us. The essential drive of that report was to further strengthen the links between the Auditor-General and the parliament and to reinforce the supremacy of the parliament in our system of government.

We are dealing with three bills cognately. I wish to take the opportunity of speaking on the details of the Auditor-General Bill, which I believe is very important. I also stress that the other bills, particularly the FMA bill and the CAC bill, are very important. We in the opposition welcome them and think they are a very good addition to the legislation.

I return to the Auditor-General Bill. I believe we are really talking about constitutional legislation and how the parliament itself properly discharges its constitutional responsibility to the people; that is, it brings the executive and the administrative arms under the surveillance of the parliament. The bill is about reporting to the parliament. In his second reading speech in the other place on 7 December last year—this is on the revised bills which he tabled on that day—Minister Beazley commended the public accounts committee for the quality of its analysis and its recommendations, the great majority of which the government accepts.

The Auditor-General Bill establishes the offices of the Auditor-General and the independent auditor. It describes their powers and responsibilities and establishes the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory agency. We welcome that. The bill lists the Auditor-General's functions, which include auditing the financial statements of all Commonwealth agencies, authorities, companies and any relevant subsidiaries. The Auditor-General is also empowered to conduct performance audits of Commonwealth agencies, authorities, companies and subsidiaries, with the exception of those that are government business enterprises, or GBEs. In the present bill, the Auditor-General has a limited mandate to conduct performance audits of GBEs.

The bill also details the Auditor-General's wide powers to obtain information and access premises. It establishes the audit office as a statutory agency. It establishes the office of the independent auditor and outlines a method of appointing, remunerating and removing both the Auditor-General and the independent auditor.

I acknowledge that the current bill is a significant improvement over the 1994 draft bill, in that it moves closer to parliament. But there are still major matters which require amendment to fulfil the expectation we as parliamentarians have of making the Auditor-General and his office fully answerable to the parliament and not just to the executive.

There are four matters that still require correction. Those matters are: firstly, the mandate to carry out performance audits; secondly, the appointment of the Auditor-General; thirdly, the Audit Committee of Parliament; and, finally, the terms and conditions of the appointment of audit staff.

I refer to the performance audit mandate. Clauses 13 to 15 of the Auditor-General Bill allow the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of Commonwealth organisations. However, the clauses allow the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits only of those Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned Commonwealth companies that are GBEs at the request of the responsible minister or both houses of parliament by resolution.

The public accounts committee believed that this represented a limitation on parliament's capacity to make an informed assessment about the efficiency with which taxpayers' money is being used by GBEs. The committee believed it important that there be an easier mechanism by which parliament could directly request the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits. The committee concluded that the most efficient way of doing this was to delegate the parliament's authority to request a performance audit of a GBE to one of its committees. In fact, the public accounts committee recommended that an audit committee of parliament, in whatever form, be able to directly request the Auditor-General to conduct a performance audit of a GBE without the need to go through the responsible minister or both houses.

I note that, under the Commonwealth's amendments successfully incorporated into the bill, Commonwealth companies not wholly owned by the Commonwealth that are GBEs, such as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, will not be subject to performance audits under any circumstance. In the amendments to be moved by the opposition, we have proposed that the Auditor-General be able at any time to conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth authority or company that is a GBE other than a GBE accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, as defined later, as a GBE with significant private sector financial involvement or any of its subsidiaries. I note that the Australian Democrats have suggested almost identically worded amendments.

I move on to the appointment of the Auditor-General. Schedule 1 of the Auditor-General Bill requires the Auditor-General to be appointed on recommendation of the minister. The minister is required to consult the finance minister, a nominee of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, the chairperson of the public accounts committee and the chairperson of an audit committee. The public accounts committee believed that it was important that the parliament be given a greater role in the appointment process. In the committee's view it would be preferable if these parliamentary representatives were given the power to approve the nomination and not just be consulted. The power of approval should also be extended to include the Audit Committee of Parliament, however it is constituted.

The public accounts committee recommended that the parliament have the right to approve the nomination of the Auditor-General and also the independent auditor. It recommended that the minister must seek the approval of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives or his or her nominee, the public accounts committee and an audit committee of parliament.

In the amendments to be moved by the opposition, we will be proposing a similar amendment to that put forward by the public accounts committee. Instead of referring to two separate committees, we are referring to the amalgamation of both, as also mentioned by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Democrats. It would be called the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit.

The government believes that the Auditor-General appointment is really an executive decision after consultation with the opposition and the public accounts committee. But we urge the government to recognise that the Auditor-General's appointment should really be by the parliament. I refer to the UK example. Under section 1(i) of the National Audit Act 1983, the chairman of the public accounts committee basically has the right of veto in that parliament. In the state of New South Wales, under section 28A of the Public Finance and Audit Act, the public accounts committee of that parliament has the right of veto. It is the same for the ombudsman and the ICAC commissioner.
I refer to the situation in the USA. A document of the GAO office reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Congress participates in the selection of the Comptroller-General—
who is the equivalent of our Auditor-General—

by providing a list of proposed candidates from which the President may choose and by confirming the appointment. The appointment process reinforces the non-partisan nature of the agency and helps protect this independence.
We in the opposition and the Democrats support that proposition very strongly.

PARA.TAB: The third matter I wish to refer to is the Audit Committee of Parliament. On 30 June 1994 the Senate referred a government notice of motion to establish an audit committee of parliament to the public accounts committee for inquiry. The public accounts committee considered that the audit committee should be given statutory recognition and that, for reasons of efficiency and effectiveness, the functions of an audit committee should be conducted by the public accounts committee itself. The committee came to this conclusion firstly because it had a long history of liaison with the Auditor-General. This has given members of that committee a strong understanding of the issues affecting the Auditor-General and his office. I remind the Senate that the government actually has the majority of members on this public accounts committee.

Secondly, it has a statutory obligation to examine reports of the Auditor-General. Members have developed a detailed insight into the Auditor-General's level of activity and the efficiency with which it is carried out. Thirdly, it already acts informally as a conduit for parliamentarians to indicate aspects of public administration that they would like the Auditor-General to examine. Finally, senators and members already have difficulty in meeting their commitments, and creating another parliamentary committee will only increase the demands on their time. Significantly, a number of former presiding officers have stated that they believe it is inappropriate for the presiding officers to participate in an audit committee as the government proposes.

The public accounts committee recommended that the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951 be amended to allow the public accounts committee to conduct the functions of an audit committee. The JCPA also believed it important that its function as an audit committee should be clearly distinct from its traditional functions. To clarify the distinction, the JCPA recommended that it should convene as an audit committee of parliament when performing audit committee functions. Furthermore, it believed that it is important that minority parties and independents be represented on the committee, and it believed that this could be most appropriately done by amending the Public Accounts Committee Act to increase the membership of the public accounts committee by one, to make it a membership of 16, and reserving that extra position for a representative of any minority groups or independents in the parliament. The opposition has proposed similar amendments to that recommended by the public accounts committee. But, instead of following the public accounts committee recommendation, we propose setting up a sectional committee to undertake this audit function.

The fourth matter relates to the terms and conditions of audit office staff. Clause 35 of the Auditor-General Bill establishes the audit office as a statutory office, which, as I said before, we in the opposition strongly welcome. But clause 37 states that the staff of the office are to be appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922, which effectively denies the Auditor-General the power to set the terms and conditions of audit office staff.

The Auditor-General is in a unique position in the public sector, given his or her vital role in strengthening the accountability of the executive to parliament and in improving public sector efficiency. The Auditor-General's capacity to undertake these functions would be enhanced if he or she had greater flexibility to negotiate competitive remuneration packages. However, this should be balanced with the requirement to protect the basic terms and conditions of the audit office staff.

I note that we already have examples like the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, which empowers the commissioner of police to determine terms and conditions of his staff, but subject to ministerial guidelines. The Federal Airports Corporation has similar guidelines. The public accounts committee took evidence about overseas examples. In the audit office in the UK, the Comptroller-General has freedom to employ staff under the conditions he wishes. In fact, the Comptroller-General stressed that it was important for him to have his senior staff swapping with the private sector all the time so that they were kept up to speed with latest advances in auditing. The same applies in New South Wales and also in the USA. I cite the situation of the General Accounting Office in the USA:

SPEECH.PARA: The Comptroller General and the Deputy Comptroller General are appointed by the President, but all other employees are hired on the basis of skill and experience. GAO administers its own personnel system, separate from the system that governs employees of the executive branch.

The public accounts committee recommended that the Auditor-General be able to set the terms and conditions of the audit office staff, with the proviso that the terms and conditions be consistent with the government industrial relations and employment policies. The opposition concurs with that recommendation and agrees with the Democrats in general principle terms that there should be an amendment along those lines.

PARA.TAB: So with those important but substantive matters, we welcome this package of bills. It contains very important reforms for the parliament. It is the parliament that we are talking about here, not the executive. If the government considers the amendments which we and the Democrats are proposing, I believe that parliament will end up with an Audit Act and associated acts of which we all can be proud. And the parliament will be able to fulfil its constitutional duty for the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Audit Act was one of the earliest bills passed by the new federal parliament in 1901. I think that demonstrates the priority and the importance that the Australian parliament gave to audit issues then. I need not remind the Senate that accountability is the cornerstone of democracy. In fact, the parliament relies on reports of the Auditor-General as a source of apolitical, independent and objective advice. In circumstances where the Auditor-General's capacity is limited by resource or other constraints—and my colleagues have referred to some of those constraints in the earlier debate—this Senate is deprived of information on the performance of the public sector.

PARA.TAB: In 1989, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts presented its report No. 296 to parliament. This was the first comprehensive government or parliamentary inquiry into the Australian audit office. I remind you that in the intervening 88 years, the purpose and the conduct of audits have changed quite dramatically. I admit that government has responded positively to that report. However, I wish to draw to the Senate's attention some significant shortcomings, most of which have been addressed by my colleague Senator Short in foreshadowing four amendments that will be moved by the coalition. So I urge everybody in the Senate to endorse those amendments because of the important accountability issues that they address.

In June 1994, the Australian National Audit Office responded through its report, Parliament's Right to Know—which related to legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901—to the package of three bills of government legislation that followed JCPA report No. 296. As a former vice-chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I sat on that inquiry and I certainly shared the Auditor-General's concern that the government's response fell short of what was required for the National Audit Office to meet the challenges of today. According to the Auditor-General, those challenges are greater than in 1989 when the joint committee reported on the Australian National Audit Office and the 1901 Audit Act as amended.

In the interest of accountability, I believe the Auditor-General should have unfettered authority to undertake performance audits of all Commonwealth owned and controlled agencies and authorities. Over the years, the Senate has had to battle the executive over the mandate of the audit office in relation to statutory authorities. Honourable senators will recall decisive victories of this Senate over the executive in relation to the restoration of audit responsibilities. I draw the Senate's attention to the victories by this Senate over the executive in response to the scope of the mandate of the Australian National Audit Office. The victories related to the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian National Rail Corporation. Frequently, the Australian National Audit Office contracts certain work to private firms but, overall, it retains the control of the work. Parliament does not have problems with this particular approach, but it is necessary to maintain the mandate of the audit office.

In 1987, the Auditor-General's mandate covered all Commonwealth bodies of whatever legal form. There were no restrictions on the Auditor-General's authority to undertake performance audits in government business enterprises. I remind the Senate that the present package of bills represents a deterioration of the position as it existed then, which was even prior to JCPA report No. 296. So the risks facing the public sector since then have increased quite significantly.

I concur with the Auditor-General's comments that the government's proposals `miss the opportunity to set the standard of public accountability and model arrangements for the operation of the Australian National Audit Office which would serve the parliament, the government and the community well into the 21st century'. And if this package of bills passes without amendment, ultimately the parliament and the community will be the losers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Word Processing Program for Disabled Persons

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want to take a few moments of your time tonight to tell you about something I learned about a week or so ago when I had the good fortune to be a guest at a dinner at which the world president of Lions International,

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Grimaldi, spoke. On the same evening, there was a presentation by Keith and Rohanne Mason of something that I think is worth repeating and for which I will do what I can to promote.

PARA.TAB: Keith and Rohanne Mason are members of the Fairfield Lions club and have developed, as they call it, a special project for special people, which is a word processing program for the physically challenged put out by the Fairfield Lions club. The program, which is called the Jenny Word Processor, is very much the work of Keith and Rohanne Mason.

The reason for it being called the Jenny Word Processor is that it has been developed for, in particular, Jenny Graham. This woman has cerebral palsy and, until she had access to a computer, she had not been able to communicate with other people. The computer that she had broke down. I am somewhat truncating the story. Keith Mason developed a program for people with cerebral palsy that enables them to communicate, many for the first time in their lives.

The program is operated by using not a keyboard but a mouse or device that can be used by a person who does not have the normal hand movements of a person who can operate a keyboard. By using the mouse or pointing device, such people can use a keyboard as if it were on the screen and point to the things to be used to create documents. This was not developed in a very short time. Over 2,500 hours of Keith Mason's time have gone into the production of this program. Rohanne Mason typed in 70,000 words and symbols to enable it to be used. It has enabled Jenny Graham and others to access a program which they can use to communicate with the world in a way that has not been available to them partly because of the quality of the program but also because of the price and the way that it is available to them.

The description read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: A mouse or other pointing device.
Optional: Sound Card with Monologue text-to-speech software.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done this because it is likely that in a community like ours there are computers of this kind available which people no longer have any use for because they have upgraded to larger or more modern machines. If what I have referred to were made available to people with cerebral palsy, it would give them access to this program and a means of communication that they would not otherwise have had. I hope that anyone who reads this and has such a machine considers making it available. Such people could do so by letting me or a Lions club near them know. The program would otherwise probably cost in excess of $5,000. But this program is available through Lions clubs for $255. PARA.TAB: The program has been considerably enhanced by the generosity of the Commonwealth Bank in supporting the project and producing the disks. Mr President, if you or others would like to see it, I have a video that describes what I have been talking about.

I want to quickly mention Nicole, who got access to this machine. She had never been able to make sounds to communicate. She was 34 when she obtained access to Keith Mason's program, the Jenny Word Processor. The first thing she wrote on her screen after she learned how to use it was `Nicole loves Mum'. It is beyond the comprehension of those of us who are sitting here to imagine that one could be 34 and not have had the means to say that until that age. This program was made available to her to communicate with the world for the first time.
I have more information about the program and the incredible people, Keith and Rohanne Mason, who have devoted so much of their lives to producing it. They had the skills and the will to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Monday, and again on Thursday, I spoke about the matter of CARE Australia and the attack on CARE Australia by Channel 9's Sunday program. Channel 9 made another attack yesterday. It would not be covered by any sub judice rules, because it is further material, so I do not feel constrained in any way to attack Channel 9.

PARA.TAB: It has come to my notice that the lies that Channel 9 perpetrated in the original attack have been exposed for what they are. CARE made an initial approach to Channel 9 because of an approach that Channel 9 started making to former employees of the CARE Australia program. Former employees were incensed about this. They rang CARE to let it know that this was going on. That was the first that CARE knew of any investigation. CARE took the approach that it would be best to let Channel 9 know that it was aware of this. On 3 February, CARE Australia contacted Peter Hiscock of the Sunday program after hearing rumours that it was preparing the program. Mr Hiscock promised to come in for a chat and give CARE Australia a chance to respond to the criticisms. It was told not to worry; that was 3 February.

On 9 February, CARE Australia again contacted Mr Peter Hiscock. CARE mentioned concerns with the way the program was being put together. If an interview was required with Malcolm Fraser and Ian Harris, it would be preferable that it be live. Mr Hiscock replied that a live interview may be difficult but that he would pursue the issue. On 16 February, CARE Australia wrote to Mr Hiscock in that context and expressed the position that it preferred a live interview. On 21 February, CARE Australia again told Sunday that it preferred a live interview. On 22 February, Malcolm Fraser spoke to Stephen Rice of the Sunday program and again reiterated that it wanted a live program.

Mr President, you and I know that editing occurs and that those who want the truth in a program go live. In the four years I was president of my party in Queensland, I always insisted on that, and the television programs respected that wish. I went live on every occasion that I appeared on television. Channel 9 said that it would certainly look into it, but that was as far as it went.

Channel 9 would not come into CARE, despite repeated requests. At one stage, it said that it would come in after it had completed its research. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on behalf of Australia's amateur radio operators, of which there are about 18,000. Many of these operators are retired service men and women who pursue the activity with absolute diligence and zest.

PARA.TAB: On 5 December last year, the Wireless Institute of Australia, which is the representative body of radio amateurs, was informed by the Spectrum Management Agency of significant changes to the prices of radio licences, although this information was embargoed until 14 December. Initial advice is that licences will rise from $37, the cost of all licences in the past, to as much as $71. This is a preliminary figure, though, and there have been some indications that the final cost may be another $10 upward of that price.

The result of this announcement is that amateur radio operators feel that the federal government has done them a grave injustice by pushing up their costs by almost 100 per cent and setting them up as easy revenue targets. My concern, and the concern which I wish to express tonight, is that the government has failed to recognise the valuable contribution these radio amateurs make to community life.

Radio amateurs are well studied and qualified to practise their hobby. They learn and are examined in the areas of radio theory, regulations, and morse code. They access radio channels defined by the international agreement made by the international telecommunications unit in Geneva. They are regularly in contact with other Australian amateur radio operators and they can also talk with NASA astronauts as they fly overhead. They can speak with fishermen all over the world and contact stations in the Antarctic. Their hobby is, of course, far reaching and fascinating.

On a more practical note, they hold field days which are used to train radio operators for emergencies. These days see stations set up to simulate emergency conditions from alternative power supplies. This is particularly significant. You, Mr President, and I both come from Western Australia where only recently Cyclone Bobby went through the mid-west of the state. I think it is significant to note that these amateur radio operators play a huge role in times of crisis such as that which was experienced in Western Australia only a few days ago.

Following on from this, they are well trained to take on a vital role in emergencies such as earthquakes and bushfires as well. For example, notice of Cyclone Tracy was first provided by an amateur operator, who then maintained a link outside Darwin for three days until other services were arranged. Even when NASA's space shuttle flight communication was lost between the shuttle and official ground stations, Australian radio amateurs came to the rescue to facilitate communication between the shuttle and the United States government.

In addition, astronauts regularly include amateur radio links in their flights for the purposes of recreation. The Russian space station MIR has a permanent amateur station installed and regularly makes contact with Australian radio amateurs. This is often used to delight school children, who may participate in a question and answer session with Russian and American astronauts with the assistance of an amateur operator. In fact, when it comes to space and satellite communication, Australia has one of the highest participation rates of any country and its amateur operators are regularly invited to conferences and seminars all over the world to assist in the planning of future satellites.

It is these aspects of the far reaching role of amateur radio operators on which I wish to elaborate. Portable radio is an effective means of communication and, combined with the vast flexible network across Australia, radio is a powerful mechanism for emergency communication. Furthermore, it is operated by people who are skilled and trained in electronics and technology and who are knowledgeable about antenna location and operating methods.

When emergencies arise, these are the people backing up authorities and they do so at absolutely no cost to the community. They are, in fact, precluded by radio regulations from receiving financial reward for their hard work, which is tireless and unselfish. In return, the federal government says, `Thanks very much for donating your time, expertise and equipment to the cause. Let's increase your fees by 100 per cent.' I think that is totally and utterly unfair for the job they are doing within the community in, as I mentioned before, times of crisis as well as for recreational purposes.

They have also played a significant role in war times and their equipment can be u0sed by the defence forces with or without notice if it is needed for an emergency military communication. With the outbreak of World War II, amateur radio operators answered the call for skilled radio personnel, who were desperately needed to operate and maintain military radio equipment and to teach each other how to perform these tasks. They formed the very backbone of defence communication in those years, which we are presently commemorating in the Australia Remembers campaign.

In fact, their efforts are commemorated right here in the Canberra War Memorial where a makeshift transmitter/receiver made from a kerosene tin is displayed. This device, referred to as `Winnie the war winner', was used by Australian troops trapped in Portuguese Timor by the Japanese advance in the Pacific and, upon their making contact with Darwin, a successful rescue mission ensued. Even during the Gulf War, amateur radio operators conveyed military intelligence from Kuwait to United Nations forces in a clandestine operation. Clearly there is a need for these operators and it is foolish of the government to make it increasingly more expensive and difficult for them to exist.

Amateur radio operators have also played a key part in important social and cultural events and are particularly keen to involve young people in their activities. At the World Jamboree held in Perth recently, amateur radio operators donated their time to link scouts up with operators all around the world. Many of the scouts also have their own club stations and these are linked up in the annual event Jamboree on the Air, or JOTA, where scouts and guides all over the planet will be talking to each other, typing messages and seeing each other through the technologies linked to amateur radio such as amateur television, amateur radio computer networks, satellites, short wave and local voice communication.

Following on from what I said earlier regarding interaction between school children and astronauts, amateur radio stations have been established in a number of primary and high schools as part of their curriculum. By using computer linked Packet Radio and hosting Packet Radio bulletin board stations, students can send and receive messages to other schools and amateur stations all around the world. For many, this is an essential insight into a career in radio communications, electronics, broadcasting, engineering or computing.

Radio also provides a vital communication link for the elderly and for people who suffer from some form of personal handicap. Modern radio equipment can be used by blind people, people who are wheelchair bound and by people who have lost their ability to speak. Aged people can use radio to maintain a bond of friendship without having to leave their home. In all of these areas, the radio amateur operator is playing an important social role.

They are responsible citizens who willingly lend themselves to military exercises and emergency operations and who give their time to assist our young people by encouraging them to be interested and interactive in amateur radio—an area which may previously have been out of bounds. It is my fear that as the price of their licences creeps up and up at the hands of the federal government their role will be greatly diminished over time.

Many operators, particularly the elderly, can ill-afford the steep price rises which are currently under consideration by the Spectrum Management Agency. Surely if the government could show it had the decency to acknowledge the value of the contributions made to society by amateur radio operators it would put a freeze on prices and engage in more substantial negotiations with the Wireless Institute of Australia before reviewing prices in the future.

But all that the government is showing at the moment is a mean spirit which has led to an inexplicable and unjustified price hike which threatens a very successful and highly respected community service. I certainly encourage the government to relook at this and, in view of the work that these radio amateur operators do throughout the length and breath of this country, to reconsider such a price hike in their licence fees.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) What is the status of the Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp which is released annually; and (b) why isn't it released as a general issue stamp.

(2)(a) When was the Queen's Birthday stamp withdrawn from circulation; (b) was it withdrawn from circulation prior to some States or Territories actually celebrating the Queen's Birthday; and (c) did this mean the stamp was not available in these States or Territories when they celebrated the Queen's birthday.
(3)(a) For how long is the Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp kept in circulation; and (b) how does this compare with other new stamp issues.
(4) How widely is the Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp circulated throughout Australia Post's retail network.
(5) Is Australia Post able to extend the circulation period for commemorative stamps if there is sufficient public demand to do so; if not, why not.
(6) What, if any, estimates does Australia Post have of the unmet public demand of the Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by Australia Post:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a)&(b) The Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp is released annually, on general issue.
(2)(a)-(c) The stamp is released shortly before the Queen's actual birthday on 21 April and, like all commemorative stamps, it remains on sale for a period of four months.

The Queen's Birthday holiday is celebrated in June in all States and Territories except Western Australia, which celebrates the monarch's birthday in October. The stamp is, therefore, on sale at the time of the Queen's Birthday public holiday in all States and Territories except Western Australia. The 1994 Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp was withdrawn from sale on 31 August 1994.
(3)(a)&(b) All commemorative and special issue stamps remain on sale for a period of four months.

Definitive stamps, released in the full range of denominations from 1c to $20, remain on sale for a much longer period. The definitives from 1c to $2 are generally replaced in a three-year cycle, which means they remain on sale for about three years.

High value definitives are replaced less often. The current high value definitives are $5, $10 (released in 1989) and $20 (released in 1990). The $5 definitive will be replaced in 1996. There are no plans at this stage to replace the $10 and $20 definitives.
(4) The Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp is circulated widely throughout Australia Post's retail network.

Distributing Post Offices, in all States and Territories, receive an initial issue of philatelic stock, which they then release to Post Offices, Licensed Post Offices/Post Office Agencies in their area, in accordance with orders received.

General stock, which is used for basic postal requirements, is in most cases sent direct to Post Offices and Licensed Post Offices/Post Office Agencies from Australia Post's Sprintpak Division in Melbourne. As actual stock despatched depends on the timing of the order received, it is possible that, if an outlet did not requisition base rate stamps at the time of the release of a new issue, that office would not receive general stock of that issue. However, if a customer specifically requests a commemorative or special issue stamp, such as the Queen's Birthday stamp, it is usually possible to meet such a request from the office's philatelic allocation. If the outlet's philatelic stock is sold, or if the outlet does not hold philatelic stock, staff will order stamps for customers if requested to do so.
(5) Australia Post is able to extend the circulation period for commemorative stamps if there is sufficient public demand to do so.

(6) Australia Post is unaware of any unmet pubic demand for the Queen's Birthday commemorative stamp. That is to say, sufficient stamps are produced to satisfy public requirements. It is aware, however, of at least one complainant who found that the stamp was unavailable at three post offices in NSW. As explained by Australia Post in its response to the complainant, staff will order particular stamps for customers if requested to do so.
