TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: The department has reported that 24 of the 27 Blackhawks stationed at Townsville were not operational in mid-January because of a shortage of spare parts, corrosion and airframe fatigue.
(1) When was it first discovered that the Blackhawks had rust and airframe fatigue; if not why not.
(2) What efforts were undertaken at the time of the discovery of rust and airframe fatigue to rectify these problems; if no action was taken at the time, why not.

(3)(a) How were such a large number of Blackhawk helicopter fleet allowed to run down to their current inoperative level; and (b) how was this possible given that Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA) has a three year contract for the maintenance for the aircraft.

(4) Does the current state of the Blackhawk fleet mean that ASTA has not adequately fulfilled the times of its maintenance contract; if so, what is the Government doing about ensuring that ASTA does properly fill the contract.

(5)(a) Does the poor state of repair of the helicopters mean that ASTA was forced to maintain the helicopters on a contract price that was totally inadequate for their proper maintenance; (b) can assurances be given that other Commercial Support Program (CSP) contracts are being properly fulfilled; and (c) are there other contracts where submitted bids are so low that companies are unable to adequately meet the requirements of the contract.

(6) With reference to the fact that the department reports that the airframe fatigue in the Blackhawks may have resulted from the addition of long-range fuel tanks on the helicopters, were these tanks added to enable the helicopters to be used for long range and heavy lift capabilities; if so, does this mean that the Blackhawks were required to fulfil roles that were once performed by the heavy-lift Chinook helicopters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In early 1992, Defence was first alerted to potential problem of corrosion following Royal Australian Navy experience with the Seahawk helicopter in the Gulf War. While there are significant differences between the Blackhawk and Seahawk helicopters, there is commonality with the airframes and many parts. Although the Seahawk is marinised to minimise the effects of saltwater corrosion, it is still susceptible to corrosion. Therefore, any occurrence or indication of corrosion in the Seahawk was more than likely to occur in the Blackhawks when operating in a maritime environment.
Cracking was first identified in 5 Aviation Regiment in Townsville in July 1994.
(2) During 1992-93, in response to the information about corrosion in Seahawks, the RAAF commenced a study which resulted in the rewriting of the corrosion protection manual.

In June 1994, an interim corrosion prevention servicing was introduced by Army. This included more frequent washing and inspections (every 14 days). This is about to be replaced with a new schedule which uses improved water displacing and corrosion prevention products. In addition, a proposal to enhance aircraft wash facilities and hangars at Townsville is being developed.
Some corrosion repair work is now being carried out during the 500 hour service although corrosion has had only a limited effect on Blackhawk availability to date.

In regard to cracking, Blackhawks are now subjected to vibration analysis every 100 hours. To rectify any existing cracking, Sikorsky has developed a repair technique, and is preparing an Engineering Change Proposal to correct the problem. As well, the RAAF is conducting flight trials at Aeronautical Research Development Unit (ARDU). If the Sikorsky and ARDU findings complement each other, the first aircraft may be modified in August 1995.

(3)(a) The primary reason that so many Blackhawk aircraft are unserviceable is the lack of repair parts. Some parts are in short supply due to unforseen reduced operating lives imposed by Sikorsky following its on-site review of ADF operating conditions for Blackhawks. Orders have been placed for the spares however because of the unexpected turnover rate of the spares, the replenishment pipeline is longer than desirable and in some cases 18-24 months.

(b) ASTA participates in Blackhawk maintenance in two main areas. In February 1992, ASTA commenced a three year contract with Army for deeper maintenance of Blackhawks in Townsville. It has done this effectively, marginally exceeded the contractual requirement, and has managed to reduce the servicing backlog. The only impediment to ASTA's ability to service the military requirement is the low availability of repair parts provided by the RAAF. The Army is satisfied with ASTA's performance in regard to Blackhawk.

In May 1994, ASTA commenced a three year contract with the RAAF to provide Sikorsky propriety spares. The RAAF is satisfied with ASTA's performance in that spares are being provided within the Sikorsky provisioning lead times. ASTA has been helpful and done as well as can be expected.
(5)(a) No. All Blackhawks maintenance conducted by ASTA is done to a high standard in accordance with the appropriate technical manuals, and within budget.
(b) The Blackhawk contract was not competed for under the Commercial Support Program.
(c) No.

(6) The Blackhawk External Stores Support System with fuel tanks was fitted to enable the aircraft to conduct long range, and high loiter time, tasks including strategic and operational deployments, counter terrorist tasks, and rescues at sea.

The Blackhawk cannot perform all the tasks that the Chinook will be able to, particularly in respect of load capacity. That is, the Blackhawk load capacity is extremely limited when the support system is fitted with full fuel tanks.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a ship with a container of glassified, highly radioactive plutonium due to depart from France during February en route to Japan:
(1) Will the Government permit the vessel to sail through Australian controlled waters.
(2) Will the Government be contacting the shipper to determine the planned route for the vessel.
(3) What is the Government's position in relation to the shipment of plutonium and plutonium waste, particularly when these shipments travel in close proximity to the Australian coastline.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The shipment in question involves a cargo of vitrified radioactive waste from France to Japan which left the French port of Cherbourg on 23 February 1995. The waste material was derived from the reprocessing of Japanese nuclear fuel in France. It does not contain usable plutonium or uranium and is not significant in non-proliferation terms. The waste has been incorporated in a stable vitreous form and placed in a steel transportation cask which provides highly effective radiation shielding. The packaging measures are in accordance with International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) regulations for the safe transport of such

ANSWER.PARA: material. The ship carrying the waste has been constructed and equipped to fully comply with the latest internationally-accepted standards of safety laid down in 1993 by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) for ships carrying such cargoes. In view of these standards, the Government is satisfied with the measures taken for the radiological protection and safety of the shipment.

PARA.TAB: Under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, which reflects relevant international law, foreign ships enjoy freedom of navigation in the exclusive economic zone of a coastal state and the right of innocent passage through the territorial sea of a coastal state, subject to the conditions laid down in the Convention. Australia, as a party to the Convention, would observe and enforce the terms of that Convention. However, the Australian Government has been informed by the countries involved in the shipment; namely Japan, France and Britain, that the intended route would not under normal circumstances require the ship to enter or to transit the territorial sea of other countries. The only circumstances in which the ship might conceivably enter or transit the Australian territorial sea would be if an emergency arose in which Australian assistance was requested. Such a request would be very unlikely, however, given the special construction and equipment of the vessel involved. If there were an emergency during the shipment and the vessel sought Australia's assistance the Government would consider such a request in accordance with the international law applicable to ships in distress.
(2) No. The Government does not expect to be informed of the planned route for the vessel although it anticipates that the route selected will become known in the course of the voyage.

(3) As stated in response to question 1, the present shipment does not involve plutonium in any significant measure. Nor is the term "plutonium waste" appropriate to describe the residue of radioactive fission products which constitute the present waste shipment.

The Government's position on the shipment of plutonium was set out comprehensively at the time of the shipment in December 1992 of plutonium from Europe to Japan, including in my answer in the Senate on 11 November 1992 to Senator Reynolds' Question on Notice No. 2424.
